name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session suspended on Wednesday 15 April 2015 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Two days ago, a devastating earthquake struck Nepal. At this hour, the death toll is almost 4 000, and well over 6 500 more people have been injured. We all have the pictures in mind. There is chaos in the country, in some villages all houses have collapsed completely, roads are torn up, roads are open, transport routes are blocked, historic sites in the country are completely destroyed, the hospitals are totally overloaded, there is no electricity and drinking water and food is scarce. The worst earthquake in the Himalayas in almost a century has affected hundreds of thousands of children and is in urgent need of humanitarian aid. We in Parliament welcome the aid that has been under way and call on everyone – the Member States and also all international organisations – to bring aid to the people affected as soon as possible. Our thoughts are with the victims and express our solidarity with the Nepalese people who have been so hard hit. Ladies and gentlemen! A week ago, another dramatic shipwreck occurred in the Mediterranean. It is likely that between 800 and 1 000 people have drowned – people who have set out to find protection from war and persecution, hunger and poverty in Europe. I know that many of you feel the same way as I do when I ask you again today to observe a minute's silence for the victims, that we ask ourselves why, at every meeting and over and over again, we have the impression that we are thinking of victims over and over again, but that we are not changing in politics what is necessary. to avoid such disasters. We will have a detailed debate on this here in plenary on Wednesday. I know – as I pointed out in the last plenary session – and I am deeply shocked, like many of you, that what I said in the last plenary session – that I do not hope to have to observe a minute's silence again in the next plenary session – has nevertheless happened. I can reach many letters from you, which have exactly that in their content. I know that is difficult. However, in view of the dramatic situation and also in view of the fact that a minute's silence is always a special event, we must not forget the respect for the innocent victims out of anger at the shortcomings that exist. That is why I therefore ask you to stand up from your seats, both for the victims in Nepal and for the poor people who have died in the Mediterranean. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I would like to pick up on a point that has been raised to me over the last few days and also today by a number of colleagues, but which is also very close to my personal heart. Nine people are awaiting execution in Indonesia in these hours. Among them are a French and two Australian citizens, an Indonesian citizen and five other people of other nationalities. Indonesia had a moratorium until the autumn of 2013 and has not carried out the death penalty. This moratorium has been lifted and the government, especially the new President, rejects any requests for clemency. The European Union has outlawed the death penalty and rejects it in principle. In this Parliament in particular, we have been working for many years worldwide to abolish this cruel form of punishment, which is unjustifiable. I therefore call – and I hope on behalf of all of you – for the Indonesian Government, and in particular the President, to refrain from carrying out the death penalty, to return to the moratorium and, in any case, to exercise his right of mercy, preferably abolishing the death penalty.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, regarding Rule 32 and the composition of political groups, you made no announcement of any change in the composition of political groups.  At the last part-session, I asked you whether Ms Janice Atkinson had been expelled from the EFDD Group, because in the United Kingdom UKIP is saying they have expelled her from their party. The Chair of the EFDD Group at the last part-session said: ‘Ah, she has been suspended’. But Rule 32 makes no provision for suspending a Member; you either are a member of a political group, or you are not a member of a political group.  It would appear that while UKIP in the UK is saying they have dealt with this Member who is accused of fraud, here they are secretly keeping her in their group in order to obtain the benefits of having a slightly larger group. Is it possible for you to do something about this hypocrisy?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Corbett. I have not yet found a rule of the Rules of Procedure which authorises me to take action against hypocrisy. However, we will look at whether there is any influence on the president. Otherwise, I have not received any communications from the group concerning the colleague, both with regard to the alleged suspension and any possible exclusion. I have just consulted the services again, and the services have not yet been made to know.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, yes, I would like to comment. Mrs Atkinson’s so—called expulsion is subject to an appeal. That appeal has not yet been heard, and until it has been heard and resolved one way or the other, she is still in good standing with the Group.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Agnew. We take note of this and inform Mr Corbett. The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 23 April 2015, in accordance with Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendments have been requested to this draft: Monday: No amendments. Tuesday: The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance is asking for a Statement by the Commission on the recent revelations of mass spying by EU citizens, politicians and companies by the NSA and the role of the German Federal Intelligence Service on Tuesday afternoon as the third item on the agenda following Mrs Macovei's report, all without a resolution. If this point is adopted, I must point out to you, for the sake of form, that the oral question on so-called intelligent borders is to be postponed to the May I part-session.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which At the height of the NSA affair, Angela Merkel declared: "Spying on friends is not possible!" What we have been discussing in Germany since last Thursday, Friday, is precisely that: the spying of friends for the NSA by the Federal Intelligence Service, the BND, which, like other intelligence agencies in Europe, may have made itself the instrument of the NSA. We have questions about what the BND illegally spied on the NSA with so-called selectors in Germany at a news hub in Bad Aibling, against business enterprises in Europe, possibly against European politicians and against European citizens. And we would think it would be very right if we did not wait and let time pass, but pursue this possible new dimension of the NSA affair from the very beginning here in the European Parliament as well. That is why we are also asking for this item on the agenda.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I strongly support this motion. Because on behalf of the NSA – one has to consider this – a European national intelligence service, the BND, has provided targeted data on European commercial enterprises. This is de facto economic espionage, and is also prohibited under EU law. You have to be so clear about that. Politicians have been spied on, European citizens have been spied on behalf of the NSA, probably for decades. This is not only a betrayal – that is one – but also a definitive break in EU law, directives, treaties that we have all adopted here and which are important. It is therefore essential to deal with this issue. I hope that the other groups will see it the same way.

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the French journalist Edouard Perrin was the third person in Luxembourg to be indicted for his involvement in revelations about Lux Leaks. We owe him and whistleblowers like Antoine Detour the special committee on tax rulings. We respect the independence of the judiciary, but we also respect the freedom of the press. The indictment proves the lack of legal protection for journalists and whistleblowers in the EU. The Trade Secrets Directive is intended to further weaken this protection. It violates the sense of justice when the decent, not the tax-henchmen, end up in court. The Commission is led by Mr Juncker, who was responsible for the laws in Luxembourg for many years. The Eu Commission should take a position in Parliament on Tuesday afternoon and make proposals for legal certainty. This also measures the credibility of this House in the fight against tax havens.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, it is little to say that, without these whistleblowers, we would not have yet received from the Commission a first tax package - in the case of the term 'package', we must not exaggerate, this is in fact an amendment. Without them, we would have had nothing at all, and perhaps we will have nothing at all in June. It is absolutely important that we encourage these whistleblowers and protect them. We must therefore encourage the Commission to include provisions in its second tax package, expected in June, to protect these whistleblowers. In view of the recent charges, a debate on this subject is more than appropriate. (Parliament adopts request for amendment)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I have no further requests for amendments for Tuesday. Wednesday: The S&D Group requests that a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Burundi be included as the first item on Wednesday's agenda.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (European Democratic And Social Affairs), we call for a statement by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, to discuss what is happening in Burundi, following the candidacy for a third term of office of President Nkurunziza.  I would like to remind you that in these days, as a result of this candidacy, which violates the Arusha peace agreements, peace could be put at risk throughout the Great Lakes region. So we are asking for a statement without resolution on what is happening.: siehe Protokoll

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, we support the request all the more because there is a real urgency. In other words, if we were to postpone this request, we would be far too close to the election. So we support the request. (Parliament adopts request for amendment)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: On Wednesday, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats requested that the debate on the murder of students in Kenya be given a different title: 'persecution of Christians around the world in connection with the murder of students in Kenya by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab'.

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We would like the title, as you have said, Mr President, to explicitly use the term 'Christians', to include the persecution of Christians. And there are two reasons for this: firstly, the specific case in Kenya. It is not only Christians who are affected by the violence, but others are also suffering. But all the violence exists only because there is hatred against Christians. The buses are stopped there, then people are asked who is Christian, and they are then executed. That is why the cause of the violence is the Christians. Hatred of the Christian minority. We are dealing with a broader question. We had not originally asked to talk about Kenya, but we had originally requested that we talk about the global persecution of Christians. Kenya was just one example. I would simply like to remind you of the figures. 300 million Christians in this world live under the threat of persecution of Christians. 150 000 Christians die every year. In the Middle East, in North Africa, we had 20% Christian minorities at the beginning of the 1990s. Today, 4% are Christian minorities. This shows the pressure Christians are under all over the world. It is by far the most persecuted religious minority in the world. That is why we want this issue to be discussed and decided in the European Parliament. The draft resolution that we have already tabled deals precisely with these issues of the persecution of Christians worldwide. I cannot understand for my group that, although we are talking about the persecution of Christians in the text, we must not appear in the title. That is why we are asking for us to return to the old title. Persecution of Christians is such an important issue! (Applause) Mr President, I would also ask, because it is an important concern for our group, that we should finally discuss this issue in its entirety and in depth – and we should also take a roll-call vote on this issue – we have tried to do so on several occasions as a group.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I strongly support this proposal. We should tell the truth: Christians are being persecuted in this place of the world. Other religious communities are being persecuted elsewhere, and there is no reason for us to censor our own language. The people of Europe are free people and we should tell the truth. That is why I absolutely support this proposal.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am going to try to separate the issue of persecution of Christians from the specific issue of the terrorist attack in Kenya. It is an indisputable reality that, in many parts of the world, mainly in this area of the Middle East, Christians are subjected to continuous persecution, which is dramatic for two fundamental reasons: firstly, because of the number of lives ahead and, secondly, because it is a planned action, carried out to banish these Christians from the area and to wipe out those communities. I therefore share the idea that it is a dramatic matter, which requires a sensible, serene debate in this Parliament. My group is prepared that, as soon as possible, a debate on the persecution of Christians in the world should be included on the agenda of the next Plenary. On the specific issue of the attack in Kenya, as the President well knows, at the Conference of Presidents we excluded the term 'Islamic', which was in the original title, so as not to raise it as a religious confrontation and, in fact, it was the EPP Group that then raised that the issue be that of persecution of Christians. I do not think it is appropriate to deal with this issue in this particular debate because many or some of the dead caused by this attack were not Christians. So my group proposes to hold a debate on the persecution of Christians in the world in the next plenary and not to change the title of the debate on the terrorist attack in Kenya.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection concerning the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on requirements for type-approval for the introduction of the on-board eCall system in vehicles based on the 112 emergency call and amending Directive 2007/46/EC (05130/3/2015 - C8-0063/2015 - 2013/0165 (COD)) (Rapporteur: Olga Sehnalova (A8-0053/2015)).

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, let me go ahead and use my speaking time. Today's debate on eCall is responding to the fact that on 2 March this year the Council adopted its position at first reading on the regulation on type-approval requirements for the introduction of an on-board 112 eCall system. The regulation is part of an initiative package aimed at ensuring the introduction of 112 eCall across Europe, which will be available free of charge to all consumers, regardless of the type and purchase price of the vehicle or country in which they are currently located. At the beginning of last year, the European Parliament and the Member States adopted a decision introducing a mandatory eCall system, which introduces from October 2017 the Pan-European infrastructure necessary for the proper functioning of the eCall emergency system.  The text submitted complements this Decision and lays down the requirements for the type-approval of eCall devices suitable for incorporation into vehicles. New types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles are to be designed from 31 March 2018 so that in the event of a serious accident, an emergency call to 112 is triggered automatically or manually. The European Parliament has long been one of the main backers of the introduction of the eCall security system. In the past, we have repeatedly pointed to delays in voluntary deployment, which have been caused by unavailability, high price and malfunction when travelling abroad. In July 2012, Parliament called on the Commission in its resolution to put forward the relevant proposal for the introduction of eCall as a public service. The requested proposal was presented by the Commission in June 2013, followed by intensive work by four parliamentary committees. The Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs supported the general line for the mandatory introduction of eCall and contributed several specific provisions to strengthening or clarifying the Commission's proposal. I would like to thank all the rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs and colleagues for their cooperation and very valuable and beneficial opinions. In February 2014, the European Parliament approved the position at first reading. This post-election position represented a mandate for final negotiations with the Member States. The Council, like the European Parliament, has made several amendments to the original proposal. A total of three trialogues and many other working meetings took place in the second half of last year, resulting in an agreement between the two institutions in December. At this point, I would like to warmly thank the representatives of the Italian and Latvian Presidencies for their intensive and very constructive cooperation. In particular, the role of the Italian Presidency was crucial. I also want to thank the Commission, which has also made a significant contribution to reaching the resulting compromise.  During the negotiations, the European Parliament managed to push through a large majority of the amendments, including an explicit reference to the 112 emergency number, compatibility with satellite navigation systems, reporting and review, or an incentive for the Commission to further intensify its work on value-added services, which could bring additional benefits to consumers as well as to the competitiveness of European industry. Thanks very much for this to all the members of the negotiating team, the Secretariat and the services of the European Parliament, I would like to thank you for your excellent assistance. The resulting text also fully guarantees the right to privacy and data protection, which has been absolutely crucial for the European Parliament from the outset. The in-depth work of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has contributed to the detailed clarification of the rules on the protection of privacy and data. A vehicle equipped with eCall will not be traceable in normal operating conditions and will not be subject to any constant position recording. The system must remain idle until the emergency call is 9/11. The data set sent by eCall to emergency services will include only the minimum information required for the proper handling of emergency calls and will only be provided to emergency services. In addition, the internal memory data of the system must be automatically and permanently deleted.  Compared to the european Parliament's initial call, the effective date of the Regulation has been postponed. The launch of the system requires close cooperation between several actors involved and Member States have asked for more time to deploy the necessary infrastructure. I consider it reasonable to comply with this requirement so that the system operates 100% at the time of launch and that European citizens can fully trust it.  Ladies and gentlemen, in the light of these, I would like to call on you to express our support for the text tabled tomorrow during the vote without further amendments. The agreement, supported by the Member States, contains the priorities of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection as well as the opinions of the associated committees, corresponding to the mandate given to me as rapporteur by the vote of the Plenary european parliament at first reading and is in line with the european parliament's earlier requirements.  Thank you for your attention and I look forward to the following debate.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I wish to thank the rapporteur, Ms Sehnalová, and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) for their tireless work on this file. Regrettably, the Commissioner who takes this file, Commissioner Bieńkowska, cannot be here today but I am taking this debate on her behalf.  I am convinced that without the enduring commitment from these committees we would not be so close to its successful conclusion. I would also like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), and the rapporteurs for the valuable contributions that they have made.  Road safety is a topic that concerns all of us and we have come a long way in making our cars and streets safer, but despite these improvements road accidents still happen all too often and, especially when a severe accident happens, we want to be sure that help is on the way quickly. However, until now, precious time is often lost due to delayed or inaccurate information about the accident. This time can make a huge difference between life and death.  The European Emergency Call System, eCall, was developed to solve this problem. eCall is an electronic system that automatically provides emergency services with the information they need immediately after an accident has happened, and by doing so it can drastically shorten the time between an accident and the arrival of help. This is the idea behind eCall and in Parliament this idea found strong resonance. One year ago, in April 2014, Parliament voted in favour of a decision that would put the infrastructure for eCall in place. Tomorrow you will have the opportunity to put the capstone on the eCall project by approving a regulation that will bring it into all cars and vans. I am convinced that we have arrived at a well-balanced and complete text. Parliament has played a vital role in shaping it and I endorse it without hesitation. As it stands, the text does not ignore the fact that private systems are already on the market and have proven their benefits. However, the eCall legislation will ensure that the system makes its way into all cars and vans in the future. As a result, many more people will benefit from it.  At the same time, data protection and privacy concerns have been taken very seriously. For this reason the public eCall system limits itself to the data that is absolutely necessary for its purpose. Information only leaves the car in the event of a severe accident and is not stored any longer than necessary. Therefore, drivers can be assured that their personal data is protected and that eCall cannot be used to track their movements.  I believe the compromise text can serve as an example of successful regulatory work on privacy and data protection. In this context, I would like once again to highlight the important contribution of the LIBE Committee. I know that many Members wanted to see eCall implemented earlier than 2018 and I can understand this impatience, but I am also convinced that we have a realistic timeline for manufacturers as well as the consumer. It will now be up to you, Members, to take the final step and turn this into law.

name: Carlos Coelho
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Sehnalová on her work. After three trilogues and a lot of work, a compromise has been reached to achieve a project which, since 2003, has been required by this Parliament. As shadow rapporteur for this report, I support the text that comes to this plenary tomorrow and reflects an added value for road safety and the lives of our citizens. It's never too much to remember that the eCall system saves lives! In a Europe where thousands of families suffer from the drama of road accidents, the implementation of the eCall system with direct connection to the European Emergency Number 112 is not a duty to... It's more than a right. By automatically establishing, in the event of a car accident, a direct link to the European Emergency Service 112, transmitting a minimum set of accident, vehicle and passenger data, eCall will allow for faster, more effective and lower costly rescue. And at a time when many say that no more Europe is needed, the legislation on eCall, on the approval requirements for the deployment of the on-board system of vehicles on the basis of 112, is a good example that we really need 'More Europe'. And as at European level we can contribute effectively to matters as important as reducing mortality and better assistance to road accident victims. I would also stress that eCall is free, secure, works in all Member States and complies with strict data protection rules. The mandatory introduction of the eCall system on the basis of the European Emergency Number for light and commercial vehicles from March 2018 will, I am sure, improve the road safety and civil protection landscape.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Dear colleague Olga Sehnalova, thank you very much for the very good, very hard work you have done and with which you have achieved a result with which we can live really well. We, as Social Democrats, will, of course, vote in favour of this compromise text tomorrow.  It was particularly important to us Social Democrats that we ensure that aid comes very quickly when there is an accident. That is why an eCall system is an important thing. A problem has arose from the very beginning with this system: What about data protection? That was one of the key issues of the discussion, of the controversies we have had in this area. I think that the solution to the so-called sleeping system is exactly the right answer. This eCall system does not allow you to track which routes have been driven. Nor is there any provision for what many private systems already provide for, namely that data on the health status of the driver or the driver will also be stored. No, that is not what we want. We want a system in which the emergency workers arrive at the scene of the accident very quickly and so only the most necessary information is needed, namely: where has this happened, at what latitude has this happened, and how do I get to this place as quickly as possible as a helper? I believe that we have done a good thing with this. Data protection is guaranteed, but help can also come quickly. That is exactly what we need.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – In December, we reached an agreement with the IMCO Commission on the eCall dossier. Now, four months later, as shadow rapporteur for the ECR, I am very pleased that this agreement will hopefully allow us to receive formal confirmation in plenary tomorrow. Far too often we lose fellow citizens in traffic, deaths that could have been prevented thanks to the faster eCall system and therefore more efficient assistance. The eCall system can indeed save many lives. By automatically making contact with the emergency centres when an accident happens, a lot of time is saved, time that can often make the difference between life and death. The system also offers many other advantages: fewer traffic jams, more efficient assistance, lower costs of interventions, and so on. It is positive that in this way, the European Union can contribute to optimising the safety of our citizens on the roads. Other aspects are also taken into account, such as flexibility in future application and technological developments, as well as privacy protection. Only when the airbag opens will data be transmitted, which will then also be erased in a timely manner. That is why I cannot support the amendment that ALDE will table on this subject. After all, they would like people to be able to disable the system themselves, which actually surpasses the target. I therefore sincerely hope that tomorrow we will be able to send a positive signal together by adopting this life-saving system.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the vote on eCall is the last step to ensure that all new cars in Europe are equipped with this alert system, triggered in the event of a crash. I am happy that the final text includes new provisions to ensure that the eCall system is not misused and that more safeguards are in place to protect the privacy of individuals.  The privacy of individuals is an important aspect for my Group. The aim of eCall is to save lives and it should be restricted to this purpose. We have to remember that seat belts have reduced the number of road deaths by around 40% although many at the time were sceptical about them. Then came airbags, and now eCall is coming. It requires a change of habits, it means trusting new technology, but technology such as eCall can help improve road safety.  For countries such as Estonia, with areas with a lot of traffic, it might be useful when rescue services are called immediately – although I would mention, to the colleagues who have said this system is free, that it is never free: the investments are made by the companies. But it is anyway an important point that it can make sure that, in the event of an accident, rescue will be on its way.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, eCall can be seen as a precedent for having to pay increasing attention to issues such as the protection of privacy, the collection and processing of data in the future. I do not see it as desirable, or even possible, that we should draw up rules or policies in this regard on a case-by-case basis, but that we must define the principles and conditions at EU level for the collection and processing of traffic data as a matter of urgency.  It is a matter of dividing opinion in this House, both between and within the groups. We must remember, however, that we are committed at EU level to reducing road deaths by half in this decade. This is not only the case with declarations, but all measures must be taken. Every year in Europe, 27 500 people lose their lives in road accidents, i.e. an entire small town. As a transport meme, I really cannot accept that we have to put the protection of people's lives and the protection of privacy or data protection in a competitive position. Yes, we must be able to take care of both. It must be possible to resolve this issue as part of the digital agenda for transport.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me thank the rapporteur for her hard work on this regulation.  I appreciate that there have been significant improvements on the handling of the information being transferred in these systems. But let us be honest, the eCall regulation will not prevent accidents from happening. Road safety and preventing accidents is about solving the causes, for example high speed and alcohol influence on the roads. That must be done in order to significantly decrease accident rates.  Of course eCall is intended to send the emergency signal more quickly. However, I think that there is also a question regarding the capacity to really send that emergency signal, and that question has not been answered. Nonetheless, for the driver or the holder of a car, having the opportunity to have the eCall system in place is a good one, but why not allow the opportunity for the person who is buying a car to consent to this system; to say on his or her own: ‘Yes, I want this’ or ‘No, I do not want this’.  What is in this box is a mobile connection, and although the data is not sent it is locked in. Therefore, if the legislator decides to get this information it is possible to get information on where a car is. This is a deep intrusion, and we should be very careful that this does not open up Pandora’s Box to the extent of tracking every car owner everywhere he goes.

name: Georg Mayer (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In and of itself, the introduction of this eCall system for Member States would be positive for me. It is also nothing quite as new, as some of my fellow Members have said here. This system is already available from many car manufacturers. It is already being applied. This system will not prevent accidents, as we have just heard before. However, it will bring valuable time: in the time between the accident and the arrival of the emergency services. However, I still have some unresolved problems here. On the one hand, I see one problem in the fact that there are manufacturers who already have this system. What does this mean for them now? Do they have to install two systems, or what will be done? Furthermore, I see a problem in the very optimistic timing of the deadline for the creation of such an emergency polling station with October 2017. I think it is an illusion that this can happen so quickly. However, the most far-reaching problem is certainly data protection. There is still a considerable need for discussion and clarification.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which From my side, too, I would naturally like to thank Mrs Sehnalova and our shadow rapporteur, Carlos Coelho, for working a complicated legislative project that has now been completed and which increases the pressure on the Member States to finally establish uniform accessibility of the 112 emergency number in all 28 Member States. On all the individual issues that could certainly be discussed here for longer, it must be clear to us that this will be an important step for security infrastructure throughout the European Union. I am pleased about that, and the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is very pleased about that. Tomorrow, at second reading, there will be only one amendment. If I have that right in my head, it comes from the Liberals. The Liberals, however, have actually argued that it should be rejected. In this respect, it should have come from the Greens better, because of course we can talk about certain issues of data protection, but There is one thing I do not think is that the emergency call should only be sent when the airbag is triggered, and then – at least as far as I know – it is always a tragic and a major problem in the car. In doing so, I believe – and I would agree with the socialist speaker – that we have reached a good compromise, on the one hand, to improve data protection and data security, on the one hand, and to improve the emergency infrastructure in the European Union as a whole. I believe that this is the right way to go. That is why the issue of road safety is not necessarily at the heart of today, but the question of whether we will be able to get the number 112 in all member states by 2017. I hope that we will succeed in this. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Schwab, I would be interested to know: are the system requirements for the eCall system mature enough and is technical standardisation in this area mature?

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much, Mr Rübig. We are already at second reading. Indeed, it is true that there will not only be the single 112 emergency call system, but also private systems that will be allowed to continue to exist. However, this should not prevent anyone from using this new 112 system, which is accessible to all. And the standardisation authorities are in the right place to create the necessary standards so that everyone can benefit from them.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur for her good work. We can rejoice that, on the one hand, we are adopting something that will really save lives, and that is very important and necessary. We can be pleased that Parliament has found a common position, has also improved the Commission's positions, and this also shows how much the committees in Parliament can cooperate with each other, and that too should be said on this occasion. Finally, I also believe that the issue of data protection is a very important aspect. We have discussed a great deal about voluntary action, non-voluntary action, etc. I believe that we have found a very good solution that can guarantee the principles of data protection. Finally, it is also very important to have a system that is accessible to all, which is virtually public in nature.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, prevention of road traffic accidents is vitally important and requires our continued support. However, we should direct our efforts at those strategies or mechanisms which are most effective and guaranteed to contribute to safety. As such, I cannot support a mandatory eCall system for four reasons. Firstly, the system works on a mobile phone signal which is patchy or non-existent in many rural areas, particularly in the UK. It is therefore not proven that the system will work in areas of limited reception. Secondly, it will require significant infrastructure investment to make it work. Thirdly, independent research suggests that eCall will reduce serious injuries by only 0.5%. We will therefore have to divert measures from better and more effective road safety measures. Fourthly and lastly, the most important concern from my point of view is that of privacy and civil liberties. eCall will mean that all car journeys in the EU and their speed can be tracked. That is unacceptable to me. Conservatives fought hard to introduce safeguards into this agreement. However, I remain convinced that, unless optional, the system seriously undermines privacy and civil liberties. As a result, I and my delegation can only support a voluntary eCall system and not a mandatory one.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank Olga Sehnalova very much for her work. I know her well, I appreciate her very much as a colleague. I have to say that one thing is still driving me around, and I can go straight to the previous speaker. I said, as soon as eCall was introduced, that this is a good thing if you have an improvement in order to be able to save people when they are actually injured. But I asked from the beginning: Where is the button to exhibit? I think it is very good that we have innovation in road transport, that we also... This is very important for us, and there are many possibilities, but everything has to do with data. Even now, if you drive a convertible, for example, that the convertible records on its own, without it being stated in the instructions for use whether you open the roof properly. There are so many things where you can decide whether you really want them or not. It has been said that the misuse of data is excluded. Yes, right, but data is retrieved from me without me wanting to. What if I don't want to be saved? Something like that can be. I think that if you have an on/off button now we can decide it – then that really is something for privacy, for the data protection of Europeans, and that is why I propose that all those who wish to do so, please support the ALDE amendment tomorrow. It goes in exactly that direction.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI).
text: Mr President, road safety is becoming, thanks to your recommendation, a priority concern for the European Union. This is already the case in France, and French motorists have become real cash cows on the pretext of their safety. Even if you claim that this eCall system will be made available free of charge, its installation in the vehicles will inevitably have a cost of production that will inevitably affect their selling price. This eCall system embedded in all vehicles would ensure the emergency call to 112 as well as the sending of a GPS signal to allow the rescue to be more responsive. The intention is very laudable, but the impact analysis you are presenting to us seems to us to be very inadequate, if not very incomplete. From 1 to 10% fewer deaths on the roads, reduction in the severity of injuries from 2% to 15%: these figures make us feel like we've come out of your hat. There are also a lot of talked about rules on data protection and privacy. These provisions are obviously the ones that raise the most eyebrows. How can you ensure that this data will not be used for purposes other than relief? Your primary mission here is to protect the economic interests, in particular, of consumers rather than trying to ensure their safety by tracking them. That is why we will vote against this project.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – My starting point is that the single market and the services it provides must function in the same way in an emergency. Of course, our rights must also be taken into account. I would also like to thank the reporter for doing a very good job. It's a very negotiated, mature dossier. I remember 2012, when we drafted the first motion for a resolution. I also remember how many presentations we've had since then, how many experts we've listened to. I think that the people who brought this subject have done quite careful work. In an emergency, you really need a system that is mandatory and cannot be turned off. There are a number of accident situations where the driver is trapped, loses consciousness or simply does not have a signal, and then the automatic system must be activated. I can therefore support all the systems that are about being used uniformly, in all Member States and in a binding way for all types of vehicles, free of charge, of course. I think that this is not a cheap development, which is why it is very important that we are able to appear in a uniform way in every vehicle, on board every vehicle, with this calling system. By 2018, there is plenty of time to put the finishing touches on the system. I think this system will save lives, tens of thousands of lives. It is our job to develop a prudent system, and I am happy to support this system.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague, Olga Sehnalová, for the excellent job she has done on this file, seeing it through from the last parliamentary term to today. Despite the fact that it has not always been easy, Olga’s hard work has produced an excellent end result, a piece of legislation which will help save thousands of human lives each year across Scotland, the UK and the European Union. Road safety concerns us all. Knowing that, if you are in a serious accident, emergency services will be automatically contacted and on their way to help can give all drivers and passengers across the European Union peace of mind and reassurance for families when travelling abroad. The European Union is investing heavily in ICT innovation and R&D policies to advance the quality of life of our citizens, and we see this with the Internet of Things. This technology creates an ecosystem of smart applications and services which interact with each other. You need only to look at smart cities and smart mobility. E-Safety and eCall are some of the latest examples of smart mobility tools and, as we see technology develop, cars are amongst the first everyday objects in which we see the practical application of this directly. We welcome the impact on improving and saving citizens’ lives across the European Union.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, nearly 26 000 people die in road accidents in Europe every year and, if you have ever been upside down in your car with your family – like I was last summer – then of course you want the emergency services to get to you as quickly as possible. There have been concerns in this file about data privacy and some of these have been addressed during the trialogue negotiations, but there are still real concerns about the intrusiveness of having a microphone link directly into your car which you cannot switch off. Maybe we should have had a more voluntary measure.  It is also very prescriptive in the nature of its technology, and I am concerned that we have not left it open for smart new innovations, because it will be expensive. It is estimated to be about EUR 100 per car and, more importantly, there is the cost of the infrastructure behind it. Unfortunately, this money then comes from other lifesaving measures where the experts tell me it could have been better spent on improving the road system or more research so that the car did not go upside down in the first place. Therefore, although the rapporteur has done a great job in trying to improve the legislation, I still think we could have made it smarter, better and more voluntary and got more money into stopping any accidents.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – Thank you very much, Mr President. I, too, fully support the introduction of a mandatory e-Call system in new passenger cars. For those who fear this new system, it can be reiterated that the Regulation has also managed to ensure adequate protection of privacy. This system will not be able to identify and track vehicles. Many such details – good and wise – are contained in it. I very much congratulate Mrs Olda Sehnalova and her entire team for this result, because it is about safety, about human life.  But I would like to take this opportunity to say that in the field of the car industry, where we are talking about human life, health and safety, we still have an extremely long way to go. And it is good that we deal with road vehicle emissions in parallel. Because, as I hear with horror, we are talking about safety, and at the same time there are countries where filters are being cut out en masse from cars such as diesel engines, illegal car dumps are polluting our environment in an unbelievable way and are a very serious threat to our health. There are more such topics. Our safety and health depend to a large extent on whether we treat them as robustly as the topic we are dealing with today and tomorrow, namely e-Call.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, roadside rescue times are closely linked to reducing the impact of the accident on the health and sometimes on the lives of those involved. That is why we believe that the conclusion of the agreement on the eCall system for new cars and light vehicles is an important step forward for the protection of all European citizens.  I would like to thank Mr Sley for his excellent report. Sehnalová, together with the Italian Presidency, for the determination with which it has pursued the objective of guaranteeing European legislation that raises road safety standards. In the eternal contrast that involves large and diverse sectors of society between privacy and security and between the identification of ever higher standards and the needs of the production sector, I believe that a fair compromise has been found in this case.  I believe that this agreement is a significant example of the integrated, concrete and citizen-close Europe that we must develop more and more, and I hope that the attempts of those who want to weaken it will stop at a rule that guarantees greater security for all European citizens.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I see that there has not been a single speaker from the EFDD Group in this debate, speaking on behalf of their Group. Is this because they think this is a bad idea, this legislation? Or is it simply because they are embarrassed that there is a piece of European-level legislation that has such widespread support and is clearly a good thing?

name: Presidente. –
text: I can only report that the EFDD Group did not consider intervening in the debate; That is all I can tell the House. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Mr President, tomorrow’s vote on the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system is not only the conclusion of more than six years of hard work on the issue by the European Parliament. Tomorrow’s vote also represents an urgent call on the Commission to propose legislative measures as soon as possible to ensure that the eCall system will be mandatory in all European countries by 2018. But most importantly, tomorrow’s vote is a decisive step towards the consolidation of a system that can save human lives. It is among the best examples of how and why the European Union brings value to its citizens.  As with most recent developments, here too digital technologies play a key enabling role. When talking about digital technologies and interconnectedness we always talk about protecting personal data. In this respect, the report puts a special emphasis on the issue of data protection, clarifying that information will only be used at the moment of a serious accident and not for the continuous tracking of the vehicle. I would like to use this opportunity to call upon car manufacturers in all Member States to make the benefits of the eCall system available for vehicles across Europe.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D).
text: – The subject is, of course, very complicated, but I would like to thank my colleague Olga Sehnal very much for preparing such an excellent report, because we have been struggling with this subject since 2005. I think that this system – this innovative system – could really save thousands of lives. And it is a great pity that the implementation deadline is constantly being postponed. Road safety must be one of the European Union's main priorities. It is very important that we adopt legislation that will improve the safety of citizens of the Member States on the roads. Let us look at mortality statistics: they are higher and higher every year and are very saddening. In addition to increasing active safety, we must not forget passive safety either, and we must continue to work to improve and improve the efficiency of rescue and medical services. I am therefore convinced that the gradual deployment of the eCall on-board system will produce positive results in the future and thus save lives in the event of a major road accident. That's when every minute or a second decides. I also believe that citizens' rights to information, to their personal data, will be sufficiently protected. There's no need to be afraid of it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, no one can question the usefulness of the eCall system, which can indeed save lives after road accidents and thus contribute to safety during transport. However, there is a question as to what guarantees are provided for personal data and what guarantees are provided that there will be no control over privacy. Judging by the debate, there are no complete guarantees. The famous principle of flexibility creates a significant gap. Data retention, even for a short period of time, seems to me to be the beginning of a new situation which will allow, possibly by amending the regulation in the future, to preserve these data for a much longer period of time.  We have not been given any explanation as to the relationship between this truly important service and the so-called 'digital traffic' and the choices that will be made. We have not been informed of how this system will work in the future in relation to the famous automatic vehicle traffic. All these questions must be answered so that privacy guarantees do not cease to exist and that citizens' personal data are not monitored.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to stress that this system is cheap, safe and will be readily available. Of course this is something that can help save injured people on the roads, too many of our fellow citizens are dying on the roads today, and that is why I am sure that the speed of assistance that will happen after the introduction of this system is something that will allow far fewer people to perish on the roads as it was after the introduction of seat belts or airbags.  I would also like to emphasize that for me as a man of this group it was very important that an agreement was reached and about the protection of personal data in such cases, and therefore I will support and vote for this system.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So, road safety is very important and the number of traffic accidents on an annual basis... there are too many accidents for me. As we have heard, we are talking on an annual basis about 26,000 people. Nevertheless, it is worth pointing out that more needs to be done on the prevention itself. In fact, the number of road deaths would be reduced with an average speed limit of 10 kilometres per hour. In any case, more needs to be done in the area of prevention, including by raising awareness of the importance of the sober driver. It is true that this system, on which we are going to vote, the so-called eCall, will not in itself reduce the number of road accidents, but it will, of course, reduce the consequences and, above all, save victims. However, there is probably room for many compromises on the protection of personal data.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the An automatic emergency call system with rapid assistance is certainly an important and very good decision if the aid is actually available. I see two major issues here: on the one hand, data protection, with a view to the telematics platform that the cars then offer. This concern should be allayed here. I doubt it, because this flood of data will certainly attract the desire of car manufacturers, but also of insurers. Let's wait and see how it develops. For me, however, deceptive security is also problematic. We know full well that there is a lack of reception coverage in rural areas and, moreover, the availability of rescue workers is not the same everywhere. That is a very important matter. Otherwise, as I said, this security is deceptive. We need deadlines for assistance that are respected. It must also be said that a great deal of work will still be needed to ensure this density throughout Europe as a whole, which we have in the core area of Europe – Germany, Austria and cetera.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, Parliament has taken a decision supporting the introduction of the eCall system. The regulation will introduce this system in all cars and vans. This will ensure data protection that will not be stored longer than necessary.  The eCall system saves lives by enabling automatic connection to the number 112 during an accident. It is a rescue system that must be available to all citizens free of charge. Member States should make further efforts to inform citizens about the importance of the European emergency number. Some Member States must invest in telecommunications infrastructure so that system 112 can improve and automatically locate the caller anywhere in the European Union, which is now not the case in all Member States and takes some time. This novelty will be a prerequisite for the introduction of a more technologically demanding eCall system that is installed in cars, which in case of a traffic accident automatically contacts the operator of the service 112 by provideing him with information about the scene, including the type of accident.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, eCall is, together with the other driving systems that integrate wireless and DECT technologies, a priority in road transport safety.  The system will provide rapid assistance to motorists involved in a collision anywhere in the European Union, and this speed will make the difference between saving the lives of hundreds or even thousands of people in Europe every year. By sending a set of data on the exact location of the accident site, the parties involved can be reached more quickly and effectively.  Nevertheless, and in any case of priority importance, respect for privacy remains, as well as the careful collection and management in the hands of qualified bodies and not private subjects of the amount of information on the mobility flows of each car owner. In my opinion, this data should be managed and rationalised in order to achieve traffic flow planning with a view to Smart cities.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the contributors to the debate for a very constructive dialogue, and it was good to have the opportunity to listen to all of the Members who wished to speak on this topic. This debate certainly made it clear that there is overwhelming support for the e-Call system and I am grateful for that support. I think overall that Parliament has once again shown its strong support and its determination to realise the benefits of the e-Call system, and it is certainly gratifying to witness such unity in general terms regarding road—safety issues.  It is primarily about new technology being put in place during the manufacturing process in cars and vans to establish the precise location and the precise detail of the accident. It is not about personal details of any individual – and this regulation provides the balance and safeguards on privacy that many of you were concerned about and concentrates on helping save lives following on from the accident. Of course accidents will always happen, unfortunately, due to driving behaviour, but no resources will be diverted, or should be diverted, by Member States from road safety, due to the fact that this is a technology that is included in the manufacturing process.  I know that Ms Ford was concerned about the economic cost to the consumer in relation to the installation of this new technology, but I would remind her that the EUR 100 that she mentioned is at the upper end of the estimate, because key components such as GPS systems or mobile phone antennae are now in many cars anyway, which brings down the costs substantially. I think it is a small price to pay to include this technology at the car manufacturing stage in order to help save lives.  I wish to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs and Members for an excellent deliberation in relation to this very important issue.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: Rapporteur. – Let me conclude this debate and thank all my colleagues for their contributions and for the support you have expressed, in essence, throughout the legislative process, which, as some of you have mentioned, was not short. As I have already said, I have also seen critical comments about the system from the outset, and I therefore believe that the European Parliament, together with the Member States, has managed to take these comments into account well in the resulting text. Ladies and gentlemen, I conclude by saying that I am convinced that the introduction of eCall across the European Union will make an important contribution to better safety for European road users, although Once again I agree that it is certainly not the only one.  The European Parliament has repeatedly identified the reduction in the number of deaths and the consequences of injuries on European roads as one of its priorities, so I believe that tomorrow's vote will contribute to our common objective.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 28, 2015. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The eCall emergency system is clearly a step forward in increasing the safety of citizens. I would like to thank my colleague Olga Sehnalová for her work. I do, however, believe that citizens should have the choice on whether to participate in the eCall system or not. I agree that measures that directly save lives in an accident should be mandatory. A seat belt, for example, can mean the difference between life and death. The eCall system could help in the aftermath of an accident, but will not prevent it. The eCall would instead increase the chances of paramedics coming to the scene earlier, in the event that no one in the car is able to make a phone call or there is no other witness around to call emergency services. Although the eCall system could potentially save lives, it is not a vital component and therefore each citizen must be given the right to decide if the benefits outweigh the cost, which is the sharing of their information.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. – Around 25,000 to 30 000 people are killed by accidents on Europe's roads every year and around 1.5 million are injured. That is why I am pleased that this important subject has finally been put into plenary, and that after a decade the 112-based eCall system can become a reality. This will save lives and bring us closer to our goal of reducing the number of deaths and fatalities on eu roads. For two reasons, I cannot agree with the speakers who reject the introduction of the system on the grounds of the protection of personal data. First of all, because for me, every single life saved is worth it to deal with it and introduce it. And that overshadows any other privacy rights. On the other hand, I do not understand the comments regarding the identification of the car. We all use GPS every day, just like we use our mobile phones. This can also be used to identify your current location or even your driving habits. Plus, it doesn't save any lives, it just makes our journey easier. So shouldn't we value the eCall system, which can save hundreds of lives a year, while significantly reducing the permanent damage to those who have been injured, because the system allows you to alert and receive help in a timely manner? Moreover, the system would be free and accessible to all European drivers, not least with significant financial savings. That is why I support the initiative!

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. –  The number of car accidents is very high and many times a phone call can save lives. I think that the deployment of an emergency call system implanted in the vehicle and based on the 112 emergency number is a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens. About 2 500 lives could be saved every year in Europe. In 2013, the Commission adopted two proposals to ensure that by October 2015 cars will automatically call emergency services in the event of a serious accident. The ʽeCallʼ system automatically dials 112 in the event of a serious crash. However, data protection is a sensitive issue. Vehicles should not be traceable and should not be subject to any constant tracking and the minimum set of data sent should include the minimum information.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that it can finally be a reality that we have been working for for years: our cars manufactured after October this year will automatically contact the nearest 112 emergency call centre in the event of an accident, saving up to 40 000 lives a year and preventing 150 000 people from becoming severely disabled. The great advantage of the automated eCall system built into cars is that it will be accessible to everyone, and it will not be a barrier if the driver has a disability, because the system will communicate independently via wireless connection to the 112 center. As early as 2011, I asked the European Commission in a written statement to put forward legislative and standardisation proposals in order to make service 112 fully accessible to all citizens and to facilitate the development of the next generation of fully accessible and reliable 112 services, independent of devices and networks, based on the concept of simultaneous communication. (35/2011. Written declaration on the need for accessible emergency services 112). I also raised my voice so that in the event that the car does not make an automatic eCall but the driver deems it necessary, he can activate the system manually so that even in the event of a minor accident, the occupants of the car can get help. Now that the European Parliament is adopting this legislation at second reading, Europe's roads are becoming even safer!

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Road safety is a public health issue. The statistics, especially in countries where highway infrastructure is less developed, are worrying. In 2013, almost 26,000 people lost their lives as a result of serious traffic accidents in the EU. The automatic 'eCall' emergency system needs the support of the European Parliament. Preliminary data suggest that adopting an automatic emergency system in cases where road users involved in accidents are unable to call 112 can save an average of around 2,500 lives annually. A 10% decrease in the number of victims across the Union is a goal that we must fight for. Life takes precedence and, given that we have the possibility of introducing a mandatory, automated system that saves lives, the eCall Report must be supported by us.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. Thanks to the excellent work of Olga Sehnalová, the European Union has today taken a step towards building a safer future for its citizens.  As of March 31, 2018, all vehicles will be equipped with the eCall safety system that will automatically notify the emergency services in the event of a serious accident. Even if the victim is unconscious, the system will inform of the exact location of the incident so that rescuers can leave within minutes.  The beneficial effects of a timely response in accident cases are manifold. With the application of the eCall system we can reduce these times by 50%. What does all this mean in concrete terms? It means human lives. In 2014 about 26,000 lives were broken following a road accident. It has been estimated that with a time saving of 50%, the system and Call will help save up to 2 500 lives each year. With regard to the critical issues that some people have raised regarding respect for the privacy and processing of data held by the eCall system, the Commission has given us strong reassurances in this regard and the institutions will ensure that the security requirements do not conflict with those of confidentiality of personal data.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on the alcohol strategy. by Alberto Cirio, Glenis Willmott, Marcus Pretzell, José Inácio Faria, Younous Omarjee, Piernicola Pedicini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000008/2015 - B8-0108/2015).

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: Chairman of the ENVI Committee. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, with the resolution adopted by the ENVI Committee, Parliament intends to make a contribution to the new alcohol strategy, which could be useful in view of future proposals by the European Commission to support Member States in reducing the health, safety and social damage caused by alcohol abuse.  I would like to begin by thanking the seven co-sponsors for their excellent work on the resolution and the oral question that preceded it. I believe that the final text, which was reached following negotiations between the political groups on 360 amendments, reflects the European Parliament's position in a balanced way.  I start from a premise, namely that our work has focused on preventing and reducing excessive and extreme consumption patterns, thus making a clear distinction between responsible consumption and harmful alcohol consumption. Remembering that responsible alcohol consumption is compatible with a healthy lifestyle, we have dedicated ourselves to the issue of alcohol abuse and its harmful consequences. The harmful use of alcohol is still the third leading cause of foreseeable death and disease in Europe and is a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases. But alcohol abuse is linked to other problems, especially social ones, related to young people's habits, addiction, road accidents and certain forms of violence, including family violence.  Combating alcohol abuse must therefore remain a priority objective of the European political agenda, not only as far as public health is concerned; We must assume that not all alcohol consumption has the same consequences, since it depends very much on habits, methods and the type of drink.  The Eu ropean Union's alcohol strategy has been effective in supporting Member States' measures to reduce alcohol-related harm, and the work of the European Alcohol and Health Forum has encouraged the development of concrete and measurable actions to reduce the harm caused by alcohol abuse at local level throughout the European Union, but we need to do more Commissioner.  With our resolution, we strongly call on the Commission to start work immediately on the new EU alcohol strategy for the period 2016-2022, with the same objectives as the previous one, but with better differentiation within consumption habits and behaviour and attitudes towards alcohol consumption itself, in order to reduce abuse-related harm. The new strategy would also have a strong impact in terms of reducing health and social expenditure linked to the direct and indirect effects of alcohol damage and helping Member States to step up their efforts to develop policies and actions to promote healthy lifestyles and to inform citizens about the harmful effects of alcohol abuse.  We therefore call on you, in full respect of the principles of subsidiarity and better regulation, to step up your efforts to improve what has already been done and to fully achieve the objectives of this strategy. In the resolution, we also call for an examination of existing European legislation on the need to improve the alcohol information currently available to the consumer, stressing the importance of clear, concise and effective information on the effects of alcohol consumption and health risks.  But on one specific point we would like to ask the Commission for more information, namely the assessment of the effects of a possible adoption of labelling at European Union level that warns consumers about the dangers of abusing alcoholic beverages during pregnancy, for minors and when driving.  In conclusion, I would like to reiterate that our aim is to make a valuable contribution to the Commission with a view to the adoption shortly of a new European strategy that can stimulate health prevention, promotion and education, reduce road accidents caused by drink-driving and make a better differentiation within consumption habits and behaviour and attitudes towards alcohol consumption with a clear distinction between responsible and harmful consumption. These, Commissioner, are the priorities expressed by the ENVI Committee in its oral question and subsequent resolution.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I fully share your concern about the need to work together to address alcohol-related harm (ARH) across the European Union. At this stage, I wish to express my regret that Commissioner Andriukaitis is not able to be here this evening, but I am glad to be able to take this debate on his behalf. Alcohol is a killer and each year 120 000 EU citizens die from alcohol-related harm. The term ‘alcohol-related harm’ covers more than 60 types of diseases and conditions, including: addiction; injuries; liver, cardiovascular and mental diseases; and certain cancers. So it affects not only the individual drinker, but also many other people, particularly family members. Drink-driving, violence and the suffering of children and families with alcohol problems are all part of the bigger picture of the harm that alcohol abuse inflicts on society. Europe is still the world’s number one alcohol drinker, with an annual average of over 10 litres of pure alcohol per person and with significant variation among Member States, regions and population groups, and yet most alcohol-related harm can be avoided. The Commission is therefore keen to find the best way to work together with all stakeholders to deliver concrete results and to reduce alcohol-related harm. We therefore envisage shaping a framework of action to which the Commission, the Member States, Parliament and civil society can all contribute.  All our efforts need to be truly joined up and all of us have an important role to play. Of course, the Member States have the main competence and responsibility to address harmful alcohol consumption, for example by setting and enforcing age limits and regulating accessibility. Just last week at the informal meeting of Health Ministers, Member States expressed support for an EU approach to address alcohol-related harm. The Commission is indeed ready to do its part to support national efforts and, as such, the Commission intends to build on the solid foundations of the 2006 EU Alcohol Strategy and maintain its objectives and tools to work together with stakeholders. When I speak about the necessary tools I mean the European Alcohol and Health Forum as well as the Committee on National Alcohol Policy in Action, and the joint action we currently have with Member States to reduce alcohol-related harm. Along with the renewed EU Health Policy Forum, these tools can help secure the active involvement of all stakeholders, and in this way we can ensure that all efforts are unified and mutually reinforcing.  In addition to alcohol-related harm, we need to carefully consider alcohol labelling. I want to confirm to Mr La Via that the Commission has started preparatory work on a report about the possible use of ingredient lists and nutrition information for alcoholic beverages. Further discussions are, however, needed before we can announce a date for the adoption of this report. At the same time, I believe that we need to focus more on health promotion and disease prevention and place action on the main causes of chronic diseases – not only in relation to alcohol but also in connection with tobacco, nutrition and physical inactivity – into a wider context; in other words, we need a holistic approach to preventing chronic diseases.  Whether or not the paper or instrument that enshrines such action is called a strategy is not in itself important. What matters most is not the tool that we use or its name, but the achievement of positive results and outcomes. I am confident that the European Parliament, the Member States, the Commission and civil society, by working together, can succeed in reducing alcohol-related harm and, as such, contribute towards a healthier Europe.

name: Glenis Willmott
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as the Commissioner has said, Europe is still the heaviest—drinking region in the world, and in Europe alcohol remains the third biggest cause of preventable death and disease.   The social costs of alcohol-related harm are estimated to be over EUR 155 billion every year. I think Members will agree that this is quite alarming and shows the need for urgent action to reduce alcohol consumption and the harm it causes. Yet the EU’s previous alcohol strategy ended in 2012 and still we are waiting for a new one. We are also waiting for the Commission’s report on extending food labelling rules to cover alcohol. This was due by the end of last year. So it does not feel as though the Commission is taking this problem really seriously. My question is, why can we not have calories labelled on all alcoholic drinks? Why should alcohol be treated any differently to everything else? It does seem strange to me that we know how many calories are in a can of coke or a glass of orange juice and yet we are not told the calories in a large glass of wine, which are actually the same as in a slice of cake. Now you may prefer a glass of wine to a slice of cake – sometimes I do – but you need the information to make that choice. Let me be clear, this is not about attacking our culture or trying to stop Europeans from enjoying a glass of wine or beer with their meal, but ultimately this is a really important public health issue – one which requires coordinated and targeted action from Member States and the Commission.
