name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, alcohol consumption has been a habit rooted in European society since antiquity and since it is moderately carried out, both in the social and economic aspects. However, alcohol abuse is the first risk factor for disease and premature death from 25 to 59 years of age. Its abuse also represents a negative economic impact of around EUR 155 billion/year. I therefore call for the renewal of the European alcohol strategy which has proved very useful and results-oriented and which ended in 2012. Central in the treatment of the alcohol theme is certainly the differentiated approach between what is different, that is, between drinking in moderation and problematic patterns of alcohol consumption, as well as admitting the regional and sub-regional variation of consumption patterns and considering the different vulnerability of different segments of the population to the harmful effects of alcohol. In particular, young people and the age at which they start drinking should be taken into account. We must give priority to issues of consumption during pregnancy, drunk driving and the adoption of healthy lifestyles. Consumers should be provided with the necessary information in terms of public health. There is a wide range of practices in the Member States with regard to labelling, lack of guidelines and some level of standardisation, which translates into unnecessary costs for businesses and barriers to the single market. Another important aspect is the definition of respect for the principle of subsidiarity and a minimum age for the acquisition of alcohol, since, from a medical-scientific point of view, brain development continues well beyond that age. We must continue to improve instruments that promote good practice by reassessing better indicators to assess the measures taken.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).

However, rather than talking about a new strategy, as in the resolution, I think we should instead continue and improve the one already in place. But in this debate it is still important to highlight the economic and social dimension of production which is part of various cultural and territorial traditions in Europe, ensuring that the European gastronomic culture of wine is not simply diabolised and thus unduly undermined.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as an MP from Croatia, I cannot remain indifferent to the latest research showing that our country is at the very top of Europe in alcohol consumption with more than 240,000 alcoholics, only 3 percent of whom are treated. Of particular concern are the trends of constant growth of consumption among young people. Therefore, I think that a new strategy on alcohol would be beneficial for both Croatia and the European Union. In doing so, I would like to stress that the focus should be on spreading awareness of the harmful effects of alcohol on both the body and the mind, rather than stricter bans which I suspect would produce the desired results. Of course, the central role in this campaign must go to the family, but I would not exclude the education system either, as I believe that better systematic information to young people about the consequences of long-term alcohol consumption can achieve enviable results.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I have been listening to the debate and I think one thing is missing. Although I am a Liberal and I tend to favour information sharing and people making their own choices, marketing – including that which targets young people – does sometimes offer misleading information. I have a problem with advertising that is targeted at the young. Research suggests that alcohol can severely damage the brain if you start with it too early, and alcohol abuse by young people is an increasing problem in many European countries, including my own. It is therefore more than time for the EU to have a common approach and take action for the sake of the young generation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, alcohol consumption remains one of the leading causes of death in Europe and is associated with a number of diseases that can be prevented. In 2006, the European strategy to support Member States in minimising the harmful effects of alcohol was presented. This strategy identified as priorities, among others, the protection of young people and children, the prevention of driving under the influence of alcohol, the reduction of the harmful effects of adults, in short, having ended in 2012 it is easy to see how much is to be done in each of these areas. Moreover, during the duration of this strategy, the crisis and the policies of social devastation that were implemented in its name not only have brought about new situations of dependence and excessive consumption, but have dismantled, in several Member States, the necessary responsiveness of public health services at various levels. We have already realised that a new strategy does not seem to be a priority for the Commission, but worse is the fact that a policy reversal is not on the Commission's agenda either. More than legislative folklore with a low practical reach, we need a real policy reversal.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I, of course, agree, of the european level, that a resolution on... alcohol abuse. Today we have heard a lot of data and a lot of information about what kind of negative effects alcohol has. However, I think that when the Commission is thinking about the strategy, it is important to pay particular attention to the strategy, that is to say, those ways of raising awareness-raising strategies, to inform people in order to protect actually the most vulnerable groups, as we have heard many times today: pregnant women, children, minors. Above all, however, we must be careful enough to do so, not to intervene in this alcohol restriction in such a way as to harm the industry itself, the economy itself and, of course, the loss of jobs. It is also necessary to pay attention to those who advertise alcohol and to act appropriately.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to congratulate the rapporteurs on their work on the alcohol strategy.  I agree with what many of my fellow Members have said, because it concerns the importance of labelling, which is important as far as calories are concerned, which is important in order to indicate precisely the possible harms and effects of alcohol abuse, especially against children. With regard to labelling in particular, we have tabled an amendment concerning the use of the addition of sucrose in wine. It is a practice that takes place, until 2012 there were subsidies for those who used concentrated must, and that creates a condition of alteration of competition between those who use natural products and those who, instead, use artificial products that undermine the originality of wine. We hope that this amendment will be supported.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE).
text: – The resolution on a strategy to combat alcoholism is very important. I welcome this fact that the European Parliament will vote on this. Unfortunately, Europeans are among the leaders in drinking alcohol, and there are three main groups to focus on: pregnant women, where the health of the unborn child must also be protected, young people who drink terrible on Fridays and Saturdays, and, I would say, in an intensive way – it is a kind of new culture, and motor vehicle drivers. We know that many diseases – there are 60 of them – are actually diseases that we could prevent if alcoholic beverages were less widely used. Not to mention serious liver, heart, cancer or brain diseases. Of course, we must also take note of broken families and also of the violence that alcoholics commit against others. I am in favour of labelling alcoholic beverages and those values that are also necessary for other foods.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we all know that alcohol consumption is a major public health concern in the European Union, responsible for a great number of diseases and deaths. In particular we are in need of more education and an awareness campaign to promote healthy lifestyles and discourage binge drinking, and of enforcement laws on the sale of alcohol in order to protect minors and prevent the sale of very cheap alcohol as well.  I support a European action plan that supports Member States implementing measurable, rigorous policy goals while respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. We need citizens to be better informed about the results of alcohol abuse. The alcohol strategy would result in significant improvements in public health and in reduced costs in healthcare and social spending for the Member States.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened with great interest to the views expressed in this debate and I wish to thank the Members for those views. I also wish to thank the rapporteurs for their work to date.  It is clear from all of the contributions that we are like-minded, and that Parliament and the Commission share similar concerns on the need to address alcohol-related harm and the abuse of alcohol. Let me underline that the Commission intends to continue to support Member States in their efforts to reduce alcohol-related harm and is keen to shape a framework of action to which all stakeholders can contribute. While it is the case that the previous strategy has expired, the work of Member States and the Commission is continuing. The Commission considers that the objectives of the strategy and its implementing tools are still valid and is co-funding a three-year joint action programme with Member States to reduce alcohol-related harm over the period 2014-2016. This involves all 28 Member States, as well as Norway, Iceland and Switzerland.  The Commission has been funding – and continues to fund – projects on alcohol and health under the health programme, for example by collaborating with the WHO and the OECD.  I know that Ms Willmott, in specific terms, mentioned the issue of labelling and others did as well. As regards how labelling for alcoholic beverages could be addressed under EU food information legislation, the Commission will issue its report as soon as possible. We are currently at the stage of preliminary discussions with Member States.  As you know, consultation is also very important and is required with stakeholders, including the role of families, educational experts and others. We will continue to keep in touch in terms of what the timescale is for the particular publication of the report, and on whether a legislative proposal can be brought forward at the same time.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: Prevention and cooperation on this issue are also very important, and indeed, as the Commissioner said, it is not about formation, it is not the name of the instrument used, but the content. A motion for a resolution was submitted to me in accordance with Article 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, April 29, 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. In Europe, more than 7% of cases of early death occur from alcohol-related problems.  25% of young males between the ages of 15 and 29 lose their lives precisely because they drink too much. Action must therefore be taken. The European Commission's coordination action can add value to national policies. More can be done against drink-driving, effective data collection of alcohol consumption in all European countries must be carried out, action must be taken on the online sale of alcoholic products and on the advertising of alcoholic beverages to minors, on the consumption of alcohol during pregnancy and on binge drinking, which is increasingly gaining ground among adolescents.  However, good mediation must also be found between the positions of countries such as Great Britain, where alcohol abuse is a serious health and public order problem, and countries such as Italy and Belgium where there is a real culture of quality wine and beer consumption. The aim of the strategy is not to discourage moderate consumption, but to support the adoption of healthy lifestyles by increasingly large sections of the population.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. It is essential that issues relating to the effects of alcohol abuse on society be taken into account in national public policies and that this issue be addressed at European level. Therefore, the European Parliament's appeal through this resolution is justified. Nevertheless, it is essential not to confuse reasonable alcohol consumption with excessive alcohol consumption. The latter must be combated through effective and targeted prevention and treatment policies to vulnerable populations. However, alcohol consumption, when reasonable, cannot be considered a societal problem. On the contrary, it is a reflection of the cultural habits and gastronomic heritages that make the richness of our regions and Europe. The different alcohol-related behaviours and the issue of product quality are dealt with in a balanced way in this report, which is essential. However, rather than asking for a new strategy, we should remain in the continuity of the strategy already in place and which has shown its potential.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: in writing. – The first problem which I see clearly in this debate is the title of the debate, since instead of heading 'Alcohol strategy' it should be called the 'Alcohol Abuse Strategy' and distinguish between moderate consumption and alcohol abuse, between those who drink a beer cane or a glass of wine in a talk and who makes bottles. These are different things, patterns of very different behaviors. Rational wine consumption helps in the development of a healthy life. Positive messages must be conveyed to the family and society about teaching to young people to acquire healthy lifestyle habits. We must also recognise the 'Wine in Moderation' initiative, which is creating very useful. In dealing with the issue of labelling, I would like to recall that DG SANCO of the European Commission produced a report in 2005 which says that consumers do not focus on caloric information on labels, but are looking for vintages, varieties and that kind of information, so it would be just as useful to record on a publicly accessible website the nutritional information of beverages , rather than further complicating product labels.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU alcohol strategy aims to address an important social and economic problem. It is astonishing that excessive alcohol consumption is the third most common lifestyle-related cause of disease in Europe. More than 60 chronic diseases, including alcoholic liver disease, pancreatitis, cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease and obesity, are at risk.  It is also important to stress that alcohol dependence is the root cause of further social problems, from domestic violence to conflicts in the workplace. In itself, moderate and cultured alcohol consumption meets the standards of a healthy lifestyle and the Hungarian health objectives. The problem is excessive and inappropriate alcohol consumption, such as drunk driving, which we need to take effective action against. However, we must be careful with measures that also call into question moderate alcohol consumption and unilaterally restrict it, such as unnecessary and unjustified labelling procedures. The increase in consumer prices would push the market towards poorer, uncontrolled quality spirits and disproportionately affect small and medium-sized enterprises.  It is therefore very important that the European Commission involves all relevant parties, in particular consumers, health organisations and producers, in the adoption and implementation of the Alcohol Strategy. Only in this way can we achieve our health objectives effectively.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. We are voting on a parliamentary resolution on a new alcohol strategy on Wednesday. It is important that there must be a clear distinction between the consumption of alcohol and its abuse. Coordinated solutions to the fight against addiction problems across the EU are certainly desirable. Under no circumstances, however, must our millennia-old culture of wine and beer production be demonised. Winegrowers and brewers preserve and develop culture and tradition – and this should continue to be the case in the future! An EU alcohol strategy must not get lost in a labelling jungle. It is much more important to launch information campaigns and to carry out active information work. I would like to distinguish myself here from the socialist proposals which consider labelling to be a panacea in the fight against abuse. In addition, I am expressly opposed to excessive interventions in the distribution of alcohol. The advanced argument of the protection of minors must not lead to a sales stop in the inn on the village square, if there is an elementary school 300 meters next to it. The protection of minors works differently – the Member States are clearly responsible for appropriate protection measures!

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – Alcohol abuse harms human health. This is the third preventable cause of mortality in Europe. Addiction, violence, car accidents, ruined young lives are social problems caused by excessive alcohol consumption. Efforts should be made together with Member States to reduce the harm from excessive alcohol consumption.  The alcohol strategy should take into account the competence of the Member States and, together with them, to raise the drinking age. Summary information on the risks of alcohol to health is important, especially when it comes to pregnant women, as they carry a new life within them. On the other hand, it is necessary to distinguish between different types of alcohol and take into account tradition, culture and local production, especially in Croatia, France, Italy and Spain.  A glass of wine is not harmful to health. Therefore, it is not necessary to introduce additional requirements and new rules for wine producers, but it is necessary to focus on prevention.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. – Combating the harmful effects associated with alcohol abuse must continue either at Member State or European level. Education and the launch of information campaigns are the most appropriate means. We all know that reducing alcohol abuse reduces socio-economic, health and safety problems. Member States must make major efforts to educate minors early on the harmful effects of excessive alcohol consumption. I also believe that we cannot deny the cultural aspects of responsible alcohol consumption in the Member States.  I believe that information to warn consumers of the dangers associated with excessive alcohol consumption, such as driving under the influence of alcohol, the harmful effects on the development of minors or on the foetus, must be rewarded. The best solution in combating alcohol abuse remains to diversify and intensify information campaigns.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. – Much has already been said about the negative impact of excessive alcohol consumption on human health or the social impact of addiction. Europe has the highest level of alcohol consumption worldwide, and I, too, believe that we need an effective strategy in this area. I consider it an important part of it to ensure the consistent protection of young people, both by raising awareness of alcohol consumption and by consistently complying with the prohibition on the sale of alcohol to minors, especially online. In addition to the Member States, alcoholic beverage producers themselves should take a responsible role in the field of education. Attention must continue to be paid to the issue of drink driving, which is linked to around one in four road accidents in the EU. Alcohol is one of the three biggest killers on Europe's roads. The previous debate concerned road safety. Measures to reduce the number of road accidents caused by alcohol would be a further contribution to reducing the number of deaths on European roads that we all want.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The European Parliament is debating the alcohol strategy today. What is the result of its adoption? For example, the social costs of alcohol consumption directly or indirectly (excluding medicine) were EUR 155.8 billion in the European Union in 2010. According to various estimates, between 5 and 9 million children live in families suffering from excessive alcohol consumption. One in four young men aged between 15 and 29 has died due to alcohol consumption. For the same reason, one in ten young women dies. Nearly 60 chronic diseases are associated with excessive alcohol consumption. Drinking not only harms health, but breaks the family, encourages violence, etc. Unfortunately, Estonians are still the leaders of the European Union. If, for example, absolute alcohol is consumed in Poland 10.2, in Finland 9.3, in the Czech Republic 11.6, in Estonia 12.3 litres per person. However, as regards differences in consumption and wine culture, this is taken into account in the document and stresses that measures to reduce alcohol consumption must be in accordance with national law and take into account local specificities. In the case of Estonia, it should be noted that the restrictions on alcohol advertising that have been in place so far did not reduce consumption, but the new strategy gives us the opportunity to combat binge drinking more effectively.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the second anniversary of the rana plaza collapse and the progress of the Bangladesh Sustainability Agreement.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, last Friday, 24 April, we were commemorating the fact that it was two years since the terrible accident at Rana Plaza in Bangladesh. As we know, 1 100 lives were claimed and over a thousand people were injured. It was a tragedy for everybody who lost their lives, for the families and for those who were injured, and it was a tragedy that could have been prevented. Although the garment industry in Bangladesh has been very successful over many years, this disaster drew attention to the shaky foundations on which it has been built. It also highlighted the world’s shared responsibility for taking action to redress the situation, given the links between the garment workers in Bangladesh and consumers all around the world. And let us not forget that EU citizens are the largest consumers as regards clothes made in Bangladesh. Through the Bangladesh Sustainability Compact, the EU, the US, the government of Bangladesh and the International Labour Organisation, referred to as the ‘compact partners’, have pledged their engagement to improve labour rights and working conditions in the Bangladesh garment and knitwear industry. Since the launch of the Compact in July 2013, health and safety conditions at the workplace have been improving in the Bangladesh garment sector. However, a lot of progress is still needed. These were the conclusions of the Compact follow-up meeting between all partners held in October 2014 and of the technical status report that we published last Friday. Since October 2014, the Commission has noted and welcomed the continued progress made by the government of Bangladesh to increase capacity and resources for safety inspections on buildings and factories, a responsibility they must fully assume in the long term. But there are outstanding issues and let me highlight them. The first of these is the adoption as a matter of highest priority by the Government of Bangladesh of the implementing regulations of the Labour Law. That was decided more than two years ago and it is imperative for the overall improvement of the situation, not least for the newly appointed inspectors in order for them to have clear rules to be able to work effectively. We hear that work is progressing, but I would urge the Government of Bangladesh to ensure that there are no further delays in adopting the rules and that all stakeholders contribute constructively to the process. It is also important that the implementing regulations address unfair labour practices, including remedies. This will correspond to the government’s commitment to prioritise effective investigation and the prosecution of those involved in unfair labour practices, including anti-union discrimination and reprisals. A matter of equal importance is that we expect the adoption of legislation to ensure that workers in export processing zones enjoy freedom of association and collective bargaining rights. I would also like to emphasise the vital role businesses should play in enabling labour rights and safe working conditions in Bangladesh. We have seen an unprecedented engagement by the private sector in all aspects of the Accord and the Alliance, amounting to more than 250 retailers from 20 countries, and between them they have inspected around 2 500 factories since the launch of the Compact. Inspection findings and remedial actions are publicly available online together with the summaries of government-led factory inspections. The Bangladesh Industry Association is also playing its role by actively raising awareness among its members of workers’ and trade union rights and the importance of a constructive social dialogue. We commend this engagement by the private sector. It must continue, including through building further on the supply-chain initiatives in line with internationally recognised guidelines and principles on corporate social responsibility. Going beyond Bangladesh, the Commission is actively engaged at multiple levels through the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the International Labour Organisation (ILO) with issues on corporate social responsibility in the garment sector. Finally, compensation is one of the burning issues and it was not directly covered by the Compact. The Commission continues to encourage garment companies and retailers to play their full part in the Rana Plaza Donors Trust Fund, regardless of whether they produced or sourced from Rana Plaza. It is important that the experience gained by the government from working with stakeholders on compensation contributes to ensuring that ultimately a sustainable system for insurance and compensation can be established in Bangladesh in the future. I thank this House for your strong involvement and support for the actions here and I am looking forward to the debate tonight.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, two months ago I led, on behalf of the European Parliament's Subcommittee on Human Rights, a delegation in Bangladesh, in Dhaka. The main purpose of the delegation was to understand the extent to which working conditions of garment workers have improved following the Rana Plaza tragedy. It must be said that, despite progress, the situation of the 4 million employees in this sector, which provides 80% of Bangladesh's total exports, is cause for concern. We were able to visit one of the more than 4,000 garment factories in Bangladesh and realized that Rana Plaza was a serious wake-up call regarding the safety of the building and its employees, with increased attention being paid to this issue. Factories have begun to have fire protection systems, electrical installations made by engineers and, above all, to strengthen buildings. It's slightly better than it was before April 24, 2013 for those who work legally, not for those over 2,000 who work in the black. This is a very sensitive issue, just as the political situation in Bangladesh and the deadlock resulting from the confrontation, the unrequited conflict between the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, is very sensitive, which does not allow for an improvement in rights and, in particular, social rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, dear colleague, companies such as C and A and JBC have made enormous progress in trying to improve conditions for workers. On the other hand, a company like H-M has made no progress and has not learned the lessons of what happened in Dhaka. She continues to treat workers like cattle. Clothes can be sold, but workers' rights are not sold. Do you agree with me that we can move companies that do not move and that we publish a blacklist of companies that are showing ill will to advance workers' rights?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I believe that this list has already been published. This is not the first time that good and bad students have been discussed. The most serious situation, I believe, concerns child labour, because Bangladesh is one of the countries that allows - like Bolivia, among others - the work of children who are sometimes only 8 or 9 years old. I understand the very aggressive attitude of the Socialists towards business, but this is about rights and, personally, I am concerned first of all about the rights of children, which are being violated. To give a full answer, I would like to point out that we have visited a very well-supported project by the Union, which aims to reintegrate working children into the school environment.

name: Bernd Lange
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done In fact, progress has been made. But things are still not in order, for example the compensation fund, which has still not been paid in by all the companies concerned – the 30 million has not yet been reached. Progress has been made on labour law – the 2013 reform. But this labour law does not yet apply to the special economic zones. There is still a lot of work to be done. Secondly, the ILO has found that the content of the fundamental ILO conventions 87 and 98, freedom of association, has simply not been guaranteed. Once again, it is important to put your finger in the wound very strongly. For me, the lesson of this incident is that it is precisely as Europeans that we must strengthen the establishment of trade unions and the exercise of collective rights in all trade relations, so that people can organise themselves and fight for their safety.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, 24 April 2015 marked the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza factory in Bangladesh which tragically claimed 1 129 lives. This tragedy highlights the challenges faced by a strategic South Asian country with a developing economy in providing safe, gainful employment for its very large population of 170 million people.  The garment industry employs some 4 million people, many of whom are women, and accounts for its largest export sector. We can be thankful now that labour and safety issues have been improved as a result of the EU-Bangladesh Sustainability Compact – for instance 32 factories have been permanently closed in Bangladesh as a result of significant safety concerns.  Bangladesh must now ensure that the regulations required for the implementation of the 2013 Labour Act are adopted as a matter of urgency. The Export Processing Zones Law should also be amended to ensure that workers in the zones enjoy equal protection.  Bangladesh recently, to its credit, increased its minimum wage, but the international compensation fund for Rana Plaza victims is still USD 6 million short and I hope that this money can be found soon. Certainly, in my view, compulsory CSR is not a good idea.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, two years on from the Rana Plaza disaster, we should be congratulating all on the progress we have made to improve safety in the clothing industry, happy that victims have received compensation and safe in the knowledge that it will never happen again – but we are very far from this happy position.  We are still stuck with the crazy model of over-consumption, throwing away clothes once they are ʽlast seasonʼ, and they are all costing the lives of the poor and voiceless people who are making them. So it is essential to mark this second anniversary. We must continue to fight for the change Bangladeshi women so desperately need. But good progress is being made, public awareness about production methods is improving, and we now have the Sustainability Compact with the Bangladeshi Government, the EU and the ILO. But, this has not stopped other tragedies like the Tazreen factory fire. There is lots more to do to stop these wholly preventable tragedies.  Better legislation can protect. We know that – we did it in Europe in the last two centuries – so let us see that reform in Bangladesh. We need due diligence for garment companies that outsource production to third countries, with binding measures on traceability and transparency. It is not impossible and it is our responsibility to make sure that those vulnerable people get our protection because the clothes they make, make us feel good. They keep commerce moving and make huge profits for multinationals. All from the sweat of their own labour.  If the Bangladesh national laws supposed to protect and compensate the workers are not enforced, if the multinational companies are slow in implementing decent working conditions, then it has to be up to us, the regulators and the consumers, to take that action.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Last Friday is two years since the deadliest disaster ever in a textile factory. 1 138 people were killed and more than 2 000 were injured. Not all the bodies were recovered. International society was shocked and vowed never to do so again. However, not all victims and their relatives have received full compensation. There are companies that make full use of these factories and the people who work in them, but who have not been willing to compensate them, or who have not told them how much they have given. Cleanclothes.org's exactly their names. But what is needed is for Commissioner Malmström to publicly address these companies on their responsibility. Naming and shaming. These companies can't get away with this. They've had plenty of time. Compliance with the so-called sustainability compact is also something commissioner Malmström must work hard for. The garment industry is vital to Bangladesh and the country is the world's largest clothing producer after China, with 60% going to Europe. We have to take responsibility there. Finally, what I would like to argue for is that we strengthen the trade unions. It is necessary for bangladeshi workers to be able to unite and make a fist. It has been shown that the employees put them under pressure, play to each other (??). As a result, employers were able to force their staff to continue working in a building that was clearly life-threatening. Every power needs a counter-force, and for these kinds of workers, a strong union is vital. We have to support them in that.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Rana Plaza should have been a wake-up call for everybody on this Earth and indeed some things have changed. They have been outlined by some here: new laws in Bangladesh, a compensation fund that is not yet filled – so things we still need to work on, and the labour law in Bangladesh still has its shortcomings. So there are a lot of things which should have been done. Yes, we as the European Union need to support Bangladesh in going further. But we also have to see that we, here in the European Union, are part of the problem. It is true that we are the consumers but we cannot leave policymaking to the consumers. Here in this Parliament we make laws about our internal market and we make laws on trade. I think we have to use those trade laws, those market laws, to make sure that those goods that are produced under horrendous working conditions – where people are dying because of the job that they are trying to do in order to feed themselves and their families – do not have a future here. So we need to have those binding rules that the Right of the House has just rejected. Maybe you can explain how, if not by binding rules, we are going to make sure that the goods that are being sold here are in line with the most decent, normal and basic human rights and the most basic working laws. I think that is something that we, as legislators, have to stand up for. We cannot excuse ourselves and leave it to the consumers. We cannot leave this to Bangladesh. It is our common responsibility.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, exactly two years ago, 1 138 people died in the collapse of one of the world's largest textile complexes, the Rana Plaza in Dacca, Bangladesh.   There were garments that we wear every day, intended to be sold by big brands such as Benetton, Camaieu, Kappa, Mango, Walmart and many others. Clothing giants cannot escape their responsibilities, they have no excuses. If you contract work in Bangladesh to certain companies and impose certain prices, you cannot pretend that you do not know and be indignant when tragedies happen. The European Union is not without fault either. Products made in Bangladesh enter Europe duty-free under a special agreement, and that is why the multinationals go there to produce, but these agreements must serve the development of poor countries, not the enrichment of multinationals, and despite the fact that the minimum wage has been raised, in Bangladesh the industry still pays the lowest wages in the world, imposing the harshest conditions. Since the disaster two years ago, the government, together with international organisations, has made progress in protecting workers' rights and has made inspections more frequent. In our resolution we wanted to encourage the progress made, but we cannot ignore the fact that even today, two years after the disaster, the conditions of those who produce clothing for the West in Bangladesh are shameful and even today trade union freedom is violently suppressed. If Bangladesh and the whole world want to avoid another Frog Plaza you need to do more and better.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I want to ask you the following: Listening carefully to your speech, you have listed a number of brands coming from your country, from Italy, which are world famous and I ask you if you share my opinion that this private sector should also and how to bear on the one hand the consequences in a way precisely to help Bangladesh, to help where it achieves extraprofits in a way that is not possible and not even appropriate , at least how do I see it?

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Thank you for your question, allow me to reiterate what I have already said, that we cannot allow through this type of treaty that allows multinationals, including Italian multinationals and beyond, to commission work where it is cheaper and under shameful conditions, thanks to the fact that they can then import duty-free from us. The aim of these agreements is exactly the opposite: not to enrich multinationals but to promote internal development. If that doesn't happen, we've got something wrong.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI).
text: Madam President, two years ago, on 24 April 2013, an eight-storey building, the Rana Plaza, collapsed in Bangladesh's capital. The tragedy left nearly 1,200 people dead. They were mostly workers, who worked in dilapidated garment factories for Western multinationals. The European Union is partly responsible for this tragedy, because, by pledging allegiance to the American model of ultraliberal globalisation, it has encouraged social dumping and accepted the exploitation of misery. What lessons did she learn from Rana Plaza? No. It merely adopted a directive, dated 22 October 2014, which obliges large companies to publish, from 2017, information on respect for human rights. But this is a decoy, as there are no penalties. The multinational lobby won. It is feared that there will be more Rana Plaza in the near future.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the presentation, two years after the terrible tragedy, of the technical report which I consider to be a demonstration of the cruelty of the current situation. This justifies the need for continued involvement of the international community with a view to protecting workers' rights and building safety. It is the best way, moreover, to honor the memory of those who regrettably lost their lives in their workplace. I also welcome the emergence of important initiatives by various international organisations, which have brought together companies, governments and trade unions and which have contributed to the improvement - clearly still insufficient - of the country's working conditions. These are good initiatives that exhort us to continue. It's just that 30% of the indems are still missing for the victims and their families. Therefore, the Government of Bangladesh must remain committed to building a stronger and better prepared state, not least because private aid ends in 2018.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – We are now two years on, but the contaminated Bengali clothing is far from clean. It has been mentioned before: eleven hundred people were killed in the Rana Plaza disaster, purely because of profit and negligence. And to alleviate the suffering, an emergency fund was set up to help victims and survivors. Italy's Benetton is one of those clothing companies that continues to fail to pay the full amount of the aid pledged. Despite all the social pressure seen in the last period, 10% of the pledged amounts have still not been paid. I have asked you questions about this, Commissioner Malmström, but you are not prepared to call the negligent clothing companies to the fore. As far as I am concerned, it is not enough to express admiration for the companies that do make a contribution. Given the great role of the European clothing industry in this disaster, it is precisely the EU that should use all its influence to ensure that victims still receive the support they are entitled to. Pressure must also be stepped up on the Government of Bangladesh, for example through binding rules. International and European trade unions point to a serious anti-trade union climate and a high degree of impunity in the Bangladeshi textile industry. I therefore call on all political groups to recognise the importance of trade unions through the resolution. That helps!

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done An important, necessary debate. I believe that we must finally speak plainly and find binding rules. The minimum wage in Bangladesh has now been raised to 62 euros per month for 60 hours of hard work. In order to meet the basic needs of life, however, you need at least 104 euros there. So what will the Commission do to ensure that European companies, as the main contracting entities, finally make fair wages a condition of their contracts? Only 20 cents more per T-shirt in purchase would fund the pay increase. Commissioner Thyssen rightly said in the Commission's press release: decent working and living conditions are a prerequisite for sustainable economic growth and prosperity along our entire production chains. Why does this truth still play little role in the Union's concrete trade policy? And is this not also a concrete reference point to the EU's refugee and migration policy? Bangladeshis are also victims of smuggling. Finally, I would also like to say that extend the sustainability pact to the whole region and, above all, make its elements binding.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Following the 2013 tragedy, the Bangladeshi government and Western clothing companies took joint action in terms of structural integrity, fire and electrical safety in those factories. But in addition to these activities, the Government of Bangladesh should contribute to ensuring the recruitment and training of inspectors, while the documentation of these inspections should be made publicly available. It is extremely important to carry out such checks on a regular basis, as they can prevent similar tragedies. In addition, the country's authorities should actively implement labour law enforcement reforms to ensure safe and decent working conditions for workers. It is also important that the Government of Bangladesh allows human rights organisations to play an important role in setting up mechanisms for monitoring human rights violations that take place in the country.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, we are all talking about this tragedy of two years ago, when more than a thousand people lost their lives. But today thousands of people still lose their lives for the same reasons, because we have production and consumption systems in Europe that are totally perverse. Many of my colleagues have put their finger on this reality. We can take responsibility in Europe by making it mandatory to trace and account for companies that not only produce in Europe, but are also order-givers and import into Europe. Any product sold and consumed in Europe should have this mandatory traceability in relation to labour law requirements, but also to human rights.  In May, we will have the opportunity here in this same assembly to adopt a traceability system for minerals. I hope that all those who mourned the workers of Rana Plaza will vote in favour of this proposal, which will go towards the obligation of traceability for minerals.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it has been two years since the tragedy, but the awareness that was created then has not moved into political action. The victims have not even collected compensation and we have not provided any regulatory framework to prevent this from happening again. I wonder, Commissioner: is there a political will to avoid these cases of exploitation that lead to these tragedies or do the human rights of the poor not count? Is it "business as usual"? We need to start being coherent and honest, to have a trade policy that promotes human dignity and does not promote exploitation through perverse competitive behaviors. We already need a binding human rights-based regulatory framework to ensure that products sold on the European market are not violating people's dignity and rights. But above all, it is essential to control the behaviour of our companies, the European ones, wherever they produce. Without it, everything else is pure hypocrisy.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is the profiteering of the few for which the poorest of the poor have paid a heavy price in the collapse of the Rana Plaza building: 1 100 people died and 2 000 were injured. Yes, much has been done, factories have been closed, workers' rights have been strengthened, at least in the beginning, wages have been increased – but far from being enough – and safety standards have been improved. The Pact was right and important. But the families were not helped. Promised financial compensation is missing. So the pressure from us, Commissioner, must be maintained on international producers, on subcontractors, to ensure a decent working environment. And the authorities in Bangladesh must carry out continuous and strict controls in their own interests. If 60% of textile products are destined for the European market, we must try to involve consumers, take a closer look at the conditions under which products are produced, and be prepared to value them financially. Don't tell anyone that the other is responsible. Let us all tell ourselves that we are partly responsible for the negative conditions we have experienced, but hopefully also for positive developments. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Mann, what do you think that the Bangladesh Government ought to do in order to avoid such tragedies in the future?

name: Thomas Mann (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The most important thing is that the authorities take responsibility, that the inspections that we are calling for can also take place, that there are sufficient staff available. The country has to get out of the situation to say that it's all happening in Bangladesh. We know that it is also happening in other countries. We have seen this – I am a member of the South Asia delegation: we only have a chance if there is really a realisation and we cannot simply say that our hands are tied, that we are not making progress. That is what we need. External pressure must take place, and then we will achieve change, especially with the authorities in Bangladesh.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I had the opportunity to go to Bangladesh with a delegation in February. We looked at the situation in the factories and talked to Accord Alliance and trade unions. There is no doubt that progress can be said to be progress. Things have improved, especially in the area of building safety, in the area of fire protection. However, there are also many shortcomings, mainly due to the fact that the trade unions are still underdeveloped. About 2% are unionized. The trade unions are rudimentary, they are fragmented. This is a major disadvantage for development in this country. There is something else that is very worrying, in addition to the lack of freedom of expression. This is the violence in this country that is more or less pointing towards civil war. As long as that is not resolved, we will have major problems. As the country's largest trading partner, we also have a responsibility to ensure that this civil war does not take place.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is not uncommon for the cotton to be harvested for a T-shirt through child labour in Uzbekistan, then processed in Bangladesh or Pakistan under unworthy conditions, and the T-shirt is sold here in Europe for great profit. While trade earns 40% on a T-shirt, it is the workers who earn only 4% of it. Poor pay, poor working conditions are the norm. We need transparency requirements, including for labour and social standards. Not just for economic activities. I expect the Commission to support, indeed call for the improvement of labour and social standards in these countries. I expect the Bangladeshi government to do something about the repression of trade unions and implement ILO conventions 87 and 98. I expect European companies: do not hide behind subcontractor chains and end the race for the cheapest sites at the expense of people, and even at the expense of human lives.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, for my group, there are three areas where we need action, all of which my colleagues have mentioned. Firstly, we need to ensure that adequate compensation is paid. The fact that 30% is still undersubscribed is outrageous, and we need to name and shame the companies that have not come forward with their money. Secondly, we have to continue to work to prevent future tragedies. The Compact is a start in that direction, but frankly Bangladesh has still not done enough in terms of training factory inspectors and more needs to be done in that respect. As other colleagues have said, we need to strengthen trade unions and there should be no exemptions in terms of export zones for trade union activity. Thirdly, and probably above all, we need to change the culture in terms of the clothing industry if this is not to happen in the future. The era of cheap labour for cheap clothes has to come to an end. That means firstly that Bangladesh itself has responsibility here because there is, let us be blunt about this, corruption between factory owners, government officials and safety inspectors at the present time, and that has to be tackled. But the multinational companies, again as my colleagues have said, also have the responsibility to ensure due diligence from the start of the supply chain to the end of the supply chain. They cannot say: ‘it is happening out of sight, therefore it is not our responsibility’. They have to ensure that good health and safety exists in the factories; they have to ensure that workers are paid a decent compensation and consumers have to accept, as others have said, that this might in the end cost them more money.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, more than 70% of imports of textiles and clothing into the EU come from Asia. Many Asian workers have to work in "sweat shop" conditions and no one reacts until there are major fatal accidents, as it was at Rana Plaza in Bangladesh in 2013. Long working hours, low wages and systematically dangerous working conditions are common in factories in Bangladesh.  Not all Asian textile and clothing exporting countries have ratified the core acts of the International Labour Organisation and their concrete application is far from desired. Unions, when allowed, can't protect workers. Bangladesh has not yet abolished the work of children. These children cannot consume the right to childhood and schooling. Their human rights are being violated. Workers working in export zones must be able to organise themselves into trade unions and enter into collective agreements and have decent working hours.  Otherwise, the European Union should not provide a market for garments that are not produced in accordance with the principles of social and environmental standards.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, I would like to ask you for three things which we can add to what my colleagues have put forward. The first: I think it is very important that we know the companies that do not want to contribute to the Compensation Fund. I believe that this is what consumers have to know about by the European Parliament. Secondly, I think it is very important that we are able to get the Commission to provide a sectoral agreement for textile companies on how to work with their supply chain. I believe that there has to be a sectoral agreement on companies, and the Commission can do a lot to get that agreement.  And thirdly, I would like to ask the European Commission to join the United Nations in reaching agreement on the 'Ruggie principles', the principles that allow extraterritoriality with the responsibility of companies to respect human rights. I believe that the Commission cannot turn its back on the 'Ruggie principles' of the United Nations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the problems of the lack of safety in Bangladesh's workplaces became known to the public after the tragic collapse of the Rana Plaza building in 2013, which killed more than 1,100 workers. A few days later, a fire broke out in the industrial area of Dhaka, with eight dead. In May 2014, in a new fire again at a clothing factory in Dhaka, we had 13 more dead. Today in Bangladesh there is a working jungle. There is no protection of the safety and hygiene of workers where multinationals have set up their factories with the aim of increasing the exploitation of workers and increasing profits. While companies' profits in Bangladesh exceed 120% and the value of the clothing industry exceeds $22 billion, wages rarely exceed $40 a month.  We must therefore take measures to protect workers' rights, we must ensure that the rules on safety in the workplace are respected and the exploitation of minors must be prohibited.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, today I would like to ask why the victims have not received their compensation. Yes, companies are taking a long time—some more than others—to contribute what is committed to the Compensation Fund, but there is a lot of money that has arrived and the victims do not receive it. And we are talking about a Government, which is Bangladesh, which is the one that signs the Cooperation Agreement with the European Union on Collaboration and Development, and it is the Government that has to send these compensations to the victims of that misfortune. I would like to recall that the first article of this Agreement on Collaboration and Development between the European Union and Bangladesh speaks of human rights, speaks of respect for human rights, speaks of democratic principles and also speaks of something that we must demand and respect from the European Union. Of course, european companies working there have to respect this — it would be more lacking!—, and it is part of the basic guiding principles, but we too have to enforce what is at the basis of the agreements we sign with developing countries.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Rana Plaza, 24 months later, 1 138 lives were lost later, 2 000 injured afterwards.  For years in Bangladesh there have been stories, stories that tell years of exploitation precisely, years of exploitation of children, shifts of 12 hours a day, 7 days a week, ridiculous wages, 40 dollars a month, well below the minimum wage for a dignified life, stories of ordinary slavery. Who knows how many European citizens wearing the clothes they wear would start to go tight if they knew how many tears and how much blood they are soaked in, on the label this is not there and they should also begin to feel itching, but above all to their consciences, not their bodies.  The agreements on fire prevention and safety are certainly useful steps, but if the funds needed to compensate the victims are still half empty, if our legislation still allows the large clothing groups to close their eyes and keep their wallets closed, gentlemen, Then Europe has not done its duty. It is time for full trade union rights to be ated, for compensation to be made and for profit to be prevented from crushing the law. Crocodile hugs and tears abound because they cost nothing and instead the businesses they have done wrong have to pay.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the day before the Rana Plaza collapsed workers did not have a collective voice to refuse to enter an unsafe workplace and were confronted by factory management with the choice of doing so or losing their jobs. This was not just a Bangladeshi tragedy but an international one, with 29 international brands sourcing garments from the factories housed in the faulty building. It is disgraceful that those injured and the families of the victims still await rightful compensation, while brands continue to generate large profits. Payments must be made. Sadly, it took a man-made disaster to finally begin long overdue efforts to ensure better working conditions in the sector.  A full reform of the Bangladeshi Labour Act is therefore needed. We have a moral obligation to ensure a more comprehensive and effective multilateral approach to make basic labour standards and minimum working conditions a priority. The EU needs to use its influence for this change. We owe this to the more than 1 100 workers who lost their lives on 24 April 2013 and to future generations. I hope that the Commissioner, just as my colleague said, will be pushing for the compensation, for future tragedies to be prevented and for trade unions to be strengthened.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this very important debate. Indeed I think there is general agreement that there has been progress in Bangladesh in important areas and the Commission was very quick, through my predecessor, to liaise with the US, with the ILO, with individual countries and the Bangladeshi Government to try to put together this Compact to see what we can do to prevent future tragedies, of course, but also to build sustainable development when it comes to labour rights, safe working conditions and a sustainable situation for the many women who work in this industry.  So, many things have been done but as I said in my introduction, we are far from happy. There is so much more to be done. We are pushing the Bangladeshi Government and we are repeating that they must do more, they must implement the provisions that they have enacted in the field of labour law, they must make sure that guarantees are also made in the processing zones and they must make sure that people can join trade unions and that they are allowed to act freely and independently, and here there is much more to be done. On the matter of compensation: the compensation fund was outside the pact. Around USD 24 million has been pledged to that fund so compensation has been paid out to many people, but not to all, and this must of course continue. The Commission is also providing support for the victims through rehabilitation and training for those who survived and those who have lost their jobs.  But we are encouraging companies to contribute to that fund. Many have; some are very public about that, there are lists online; some are contributing without giving their names; some are not willing to put down the figures and with others we are pushing for them to contribute. Many companies have contributed to inspection. More than 2 500 inspections have been carried out and we have jointly trained inspectors to be looking at this as well. The Commission will continue to monitor this situation very closely. As I said, we have just issued a report on implementation of the Compact which is available for Members to read and we have also made a joint statement with the US on what needs to be done further. In that report there is, as many Members asked, a reference to minimum wages and we will continue to monitor this very closely, in cooperation with partners in the Compact but also together with the Bangladeshi Government, working with them, pushing them, to do their part in this.  We are also considering a high-level follow-up meeting in Dhaka later this autumn to take stock, on the spot, of where progress has been made and what is still to be done, and I will be happy to continue the dialogue with this House on this issue. So I hope that we can soon be in a position to report further progress while knowing that this is not a situation that will change very quickly. We are also, as many Members mentioned, working on the issues of due diligence and responsible value chains with the ILO, with the OECD and with other partners. The Communication that the Commission is preparing for the autumn, in which we will outline our priorities for trade for the coming five years, will also play a role: sustainable value change, encouraging companies to exercise due diligence and to see what we have learned from the whole tragic Bangladeshi experience, to put that in the future strategy as well. In this, of course, I am looking forward to working with the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and others as well. We owe it to the victims of Rana Plaza and their families not only to commemorate the tragic events but also to make sure that we really bring about long-term change. It is not easy, it will not change overnight but we can do more, we are doing more and, honourable Members, you can count on the Commission to keep on monitoring this very closely; I am also counting on you. I know that many of you have been in Bangladesh, many of you are following this very closely. So let us together do what we can to make sure that change is not temporary but really sustainable.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, April 29, 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Arne Lietz (S&D)
text: Writing. I support the call by my fellow Members and the Commissioner for all companies to finally pay into the compensation fund for victims and their families. It is essential that European legislation forces companies to be able to track their supply chains in order to meet ILO labour standards for workers. Initiatives in this direction are already under way through textile alliances in the Netherlands, Denmark and also in Germany. Our aim in the European Parliament and in the Commission must be to pool and strengthen these initiatives at European level.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Where are we two years after the collapse of the Rana Plaza textile factory in Bangladesh, which claimed the lives of 1,134 workers? What about the working conditions, safety and health of Bangladeshi workers? While there is progress, efforts remain to be made. Agreements have been signed to strengthen inspections at factories and improve safety standards. Wages have been increased and changes to the Trade Union Training Act have also strengthened the capacity of trade unions at the national level. The European Union has contributed to these advances, thanks in particular to the active support of the International Labour Organization. It has a vital role to play in preventing similar disasters from happening again. It should be remembered that 60% of the country's clothing exports go to the EU! In these circumstances, Europe must take responsibility by pleading with the Bangladeshi authorities, as well as the major brands that employ this low-cost workforce, to adopt better workplace safety systems. It is a question of ethics and humanity!

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "There have been a number of tragedies in clothing factories in Bangladesh, the most serious of which was the collapse of the Rana Plaza building. This disaster is one of the most tragic examples of human rights abuses in the commercial sector, and the pictures of workers killed in the ruins of a collapsed factory have become a poignant symbol of the pursuit of profit at the expense of people's lives and health. We are here today to commemorate the victims of this disaster and to show our respect for their families. Despite some labour law reforms, workers continue to report harassment and intimidation in order to prevent them from forming or entering trade unions. I call on the Government of Bangladesh to ensure that labour law is enforced and that further reforms be carried out in order to bring the law into compliance with International Labour Organisation standards. The Bangladeshi authorities must strengthen their capacity to control the clothing industry and increase the resources available to authorities responsible for construction and fire safety. It is worrying that violence and discrimination are being used against trade union members, and I would also like to call for effective investigations into unfair practices. Two years after the disaster, in which more than 1,100 people died and 2,500 were injured, survivors and families of victims are still waiting to be compensated. Many of them are out of work and require medical care. Therefore, clothing companies must take responsibility for workers in Asian factories.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today we remember one of the most serious disasters that occurred in 2013. 1,127 people lost their lives in the collapse of the Savar building in Bangladesh. Poor working conditions, lack of vigilance and the instrumentalization of human capital led to the die of 1,127 people. A year earlier, in 2012, in a factory fire, also in Bangladesh, 112 people lost their lives. Europe was shocked by these events; however, it was not the first time they had happened. It is important that, from here, we continue to denounce these facts. We must stress the need for more rigorous control of production chains. Our companies must commit to working with suppliers that ensure the health and safety of workers. In commemoration of the anniversary of this tragedy, we note that virtually nothing has changed. Bangladesh must ensure a system of safety and work inspections. I call from here for the implementation of the eight ILO Conventions; to give a boost to the Sustainability Pact to improve working conditions, health and safety of workers as well as to promote the responsible behaviour of textile companies in Bangladesh.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the report by Jarosław Wałęsa on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, debate on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and their fisheries (COM(2014)0614 - C8-0174/2014 - 2014/0285(COD)).

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, this multi-species plan has been long awaited. I believe this approach is much more effective than management based on a single species. It aims to take account of interspecies interactions, such as the influence of the cod stock on herring and sprat stocks, and the other way around.  The plan should provide for a balanced, sustainable exploitation of these stocks and for the stability of fishing opportunities and thereby the livelihoods of fishers. At the same time, it should guarantee that management is based on the most up-to-date scientific advice regarding the status of the stocks covered, interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries. The most controversial part of this dossier concerns the scientific advice, namely target fishing mortality ranges as set out in Article 4 and Article 5. To explain to our non-fisheries Members, those ranges will indicate how much fish fishermen will be allowed to fish. Obviously the smaller the range of values, the smaller the amount of fish; and the broader the range, the more flexibility for the sector from one year to another. Values in the Commission’s proposals are provided by the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) which is the scientific advisory body of the Commission. These figures are advised after careful analysis of all available data and applying scientifically reviewed and tested models. Some may say that the values of those ranges provided by the Commission were not in line with the reformed common fisheries policy (CFP). Frankly, that is partly true. They are not yet in line, but only because we have until 2020 to reach the targets set out in the reform. The basic regulation says: ‘In order to reach the objective of [...] restoring and maintaining populations of fish stocks above biomass levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield, the maximum sustainable yield exploitation rate shall be achieved by 2015 where possible and, on a progressive, incremental basis at the latest by 2020 for all stocks.’ So we have five years to fulfil the obligation of the reform of the CFP.  While setting fishing mortality targets, we should also take into account the most recent scientific advice. Let us not forget that we are politicians; we are not scientists. We should not play around with arbitrary formulas. We should listen to the scientists and wisely use their advice.  At the same time, I want to dispel some doubts. It is probable that future plans will be modelled on the Baltic Plan, but only in terms of structure. In terms of content, the principle of regionalisation will be applied. Therefore what we adopt for the Baltic cannot be copied for the Mediterranean or the North Sea. This also includes the targets. However, on the contrary, accepting arbitrary formulas would create a very dangerous precedent. This means that such an approach would also be used in other future plans for the North Sea or the Mediterranean Sea. How are we going to explain this to the fishermen? Many amendments have been tabled asking to follow the most scientific advice and this is exactly what I try to do. I want to use the FMSY (fishing mortality consistent with Maximum Sustainable Yield) figures advised by the scientific body, ICES, wisely.  Finally, I would also like to underline that I am against including seabirds and sea mammals in the text of the Fisheries Management Plan because we have different legislation for that. Let us not experiment with the Baltic. Let us follow science. Let us not mix the legislation and let us not confuse politics with science.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Wałęsa, and all the Members of this House, who have contributed to the quality of the work on the Baltic management plan which was done in, I would say, a very short time. This is a big step forward for the European Union’s Common Fisheries Policy and I am very happy that, again, Parliament has taken the lead in making that step possible.  With your vote this week we will come one step closer to a modern fisheries policy that our citizens and the fishing sector can understand and support. The Council, under the Latvian Presidency, has also made considerable progress. Last Monday, it adopted its general approach on the Commission’s proposal. I believe that by maintaining this momentum we can finalise the plan by the end of this year.  This is the first multiannual fisheries management plan after the adoption of the new Common Fisheries Policy. We have to make this plan work to prove that the reform, as intended, can bring benefits to our fishermen, increase their income and provide for the sustainability of the fish resources. Those benefits include regional decision-making by those who know the regions best. They include more flexibility in setting fishing opportunities, and they include sustainability of the fish stocks on which local stakeholders rely. Allow me now to make a few comments on the report that you will adopt this week. As a Commissioner not only for fisheries but also for the environment, I welcome the amendments to include references to the Union environmental legislation. I believe this will strengthen the coherence between our two policies. I would also like to stress that the scientific advice has always been, and will always remain, the core element for decision-making in fisheries management. This is something that we must base our decisions upon when we manage our fisheries. The Commission has always followed the most recent and the most up-to-date scientific advice, as has already been mentioned by the rapporteur Mr Wałęsa, and I can assure you it will continue to do so.  I am certain we will have an interesting, lively and constructive debate and hopefully we can make good progress very soon after this week’s vote, but let me say one more thing. This plan is not only very important for the Baltic region and the countries that are directly concerned, but it will also be a positive precedent for other management plans to be adopted in the future. So let us work together to reach our shared objectives of our common fisheries policy.

name: Gabriel Mato
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the Baltic plan is particularly relevant for many reasons, including because of its necessary adaptation to a new competition framework set out in the Lisbon Treaty, to which it must be added that it is the first one we adopted with the new common fisheries policy and which also envisages the newly launched concept of regionalisation. It is clear that we are looking at a plan that has to be implemented in a specific geographical area with particular fishing characteristics, but also that it can somehow mark the future of other plans, and that is why we have to make sure that we get things right. It is committed to long-term management rather than annual planning, which will allow fishermen to make their forecasts while ensuring that they are always fished according to Baltic catch capacity. The rapporteur has tried to maintain a balance between the powers by making scientifically-based proposals and presenting a solution to the fishing mortality target, a sensible solution that ensures a balance and clashes head-on with those who propose, arbitrarily and without any scientific basis, percentage reductions that ignore factors to be taken into account. Let us maintain a reasonable position on this issue, because here the important thing is to ensure the present and future of an ecosystem as sensitive as the Baltic Sea while providing our fishermen with a more stable and secure framework that will enable them to guarantee their activity in the future.

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for According to the basic Regulation, multiannual plans are a tool, an anchor for the sustainable management of fish stocks and the ecosystem. This is the first proposal for a multiannual plan after the entry into force of the new CFP reform and at the same time a blueprint for subsequent plans. The Commission's proposal for a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea does not fully meet the objectives of the reform. We do not want the CFP to be watered down, but an improvement. Contrary to the CFP reform, Article 3 – objectives of the proposal – does not set the objective of replenishing and maintaining the fish population above a biomass level guaranteed by the MSY. The Commission's explanatory memorandum does not explicitly take into account the interactions between these stocks – cod, herring and sprat – and other ecosystems. The point of contention is Article 4 - Target values. Here we want to limit the target for fishing mortality. It is good that the Commission proposal does not include an annual restriction on fishing effort. This means that the restriction on the number of fishing days that must not be exceeded, which fishermen often complain about, is finally off the table.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his great commitment to the preparation of this report. It offers one last chance to rebuild baltic resources and to protect the species properly. It should be recalled that until now, even sprat has been treated as a pest, negatively affecting the cod population due to the nutrition of its spine. It was caught uncontrollably for industrial purposes. In this way, the food chain was interrupted and the cod population and pelagic species collapsed. The only way to restore baltic resources is to temporarily cease all fishing and introduce conservation and compensation programmes for fishermen. This is the only way to guarantee and preserve fisheries, especially family fisheries, while ensuring its development.
