In the light of its disastrous policy so far, the European Union is responsible for protecting the environment and supporting fisheries, especially family fishing.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking my colleague Mr Wałęsa for his work. Here we have all the fighters from the reform of the common fisheries policy, with Mrs Rodust and Gabriel Mato and Mr Gróbarczyk. I think this is a great step forward because we know that the plan for the Baltic will be a blueprint for the rest of the multi-species plans to be made. We have therefore been very careful to produce a report that can serve as the blueprint and we have therefore been very careful with the facts and background work. I would just like to add that I have tabled an amendment just to get the latest scientific figures into the report.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The Baltic Sea is a unique area. At the same time, we are also seeing the sad model of European fisheries policy. Everything that is wrong with that, we see in the Baltic Sea. The trend has been the same for years: fewer fish every year! Biodiversity is still declining. Virtually all fish populations are overfished. Cod, for example, is therefore even seriously threatened in its survival. Time and time again, Member States set catch limits that are much higher than scientific advice. We hope that this proposal will at least put an end to this. As if overfishing were not enough, we see that other environmental impacts also threaten biodiversity in the Baltic Sea, for example animal manure, which allows a great deal of algae to grow. That is also why I believe that European agricultural and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Many of us here today want the Baltic Sea to become a healthy sea again. You should be able to eat locally caught cod without having to worry that it is disappearing. Major steps have already been taken to make this a reality. After a long battle, European politicians agreed the other year that we must stop overfishing. All of us who have fought for the new EU fishing law, which says that you cannot fish more than the sea can tolerate, are proud and want to see political action in the same direction. We are on the right track, but there is still much to be done. Cod in the Baltic Sea is not doing well. After a positive development over a few years, the number of cod is now falling again. The ones that exist are small and skinny. It is possible to reverse the trend if all countries around our sensitive inland sea cooperate. By reducing fishing for a number of years, we are giving cod a chance to recover. It is important to take a holistic approach that takes account of the fact that all species in the sea affect each other, so that, for example, the larger predatory fish are not deprived of their food. The EU is now to adopt a management plan for cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. For us, it goes without saying that the plan will lead to sustainable fishing and a long-term good marine environment. We have therefore put forward proposals to ensure that catches of fish should be at such levels that fish stocks can grow larger. However, not all our colleagues in the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers agree. There are strong forces that are countering sustainable fishing. The Baltic Sea Plan will be a model for future management plans in different maritime areas of the EU. That is why it is especially important that it be right this time.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the multiannual plans as provided for in the common fisheries policy aim to restore and maintain fish stocks above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield, it is a fundamental point of the common policy, an approach to fisheries management from which we can no longer ignore.  The Multiannual Baltic Plan is the first application of this type and is therefore an important test case for the multiannual plans that will follow. It introduces new concepts such as an ecosystem approach, although not fully transposed as the maximum sustainable yield. The European Parliament, at least to a large part, seems to have taken on board this spirit, contrary to the Council's apparently, which faces new challenges but looking to the past, forgetting that it is precisely the attitude and the idea of considering fish stocks as infinite that has led to the situation of serious crisis in stocks and fisheries itself.  With tomorrow's vote, we must firmly support the position of the European Parliament and show that the turning point in the common fisheries policy is real and that the objective of putting an end to overfishing is possible. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Madam President, Dear Mr. Advocate, thank you for accepting the blue card. I'd like to ask you after careful listening. You said that the Baltic Sea as the first such is one example of a comprehensive approach to the fishing and use of resources that exist in the Baltics. Do you think, like me, that such a similar approach should be for the Adriatic Sea, which is a small, closed sea, where we should really have the principles of harvesting all kinds and a truly scientific approach to preserve resources on one small closed sea such as the Adriatic?

name: Marco Affronte (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I thank you for your question, because I live on the Adriatic, I am from Rimini, I live on the Adriatic coast, so I absolutely believe that the model that we are beginning to build and that we have used as a test in the Baltic Sea, must gradually be implemented with the multiannual plans also in other basins, particularly in the Mediterranean where the situation of overfishing is very , very serious and also for smaller basins, but very fished, such as the Adriatic.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI).
text: Madam President, a few words to say that this plan for cod, herring and sprat has, in a way, the defects of its qualities. Since it is a matter of saving threatened stocks, this plan is intended to be quite drastic, which can of course be understood. But it is difficult to accept the excessive use of acts delegated by Parliament to the European Commission. This plan is, in this respect, symptomatic of a Parliament which renounces its prerogatives and entrusts them to the Commission. As for the Member States, they themselves are excluded from decision-making, despite the principle of regionalisation of the common fisheries policy. We are therefore particularly wary of the technical measures that the Commission would have to adopt without always having relevant and regularly updated scientific studies.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Vella, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his Many thanks to Mr Wasa, who has done a good job here. The common fisheries policy for the next ten to fifteen years also needs reliable and sensible management plans. This is not a magic work that is being tackled here, but it is clear cooperation between the profession and science. And it is only on a scientific basis that the individual stocks can be assessed sensibly. We have institutes and marine biologists who provide the basis for sprat, herring and cod. And then we have the MSY standard of fishing, which we want to comply with. That is what it is all about in principle. Fishermen have already had to accept enormous quota cuts in recent years and have now also taken stocks to such a level that they can be fished sensibly and also sustainably fished, and this multi-annual multi-annual plan is very important so that there are no excessive demands with 0.8 MSY etc., but feasible in practice.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D).
text: Madam President! I am pleased that this week we can vote on two important pieces of legislation. I am pleased that we have had a fairly rapid examination of the multiannual management plan for the Baltic Sea. Now we must look ahead to the preparation of the new technical measures, new discard plans and new management plans. In this context, we must become better at taking regional advisory bodies on board, and we must ensure that fishermen are given as much responsibility and freedom in relation to tool choices as possible. When we have fishing subject to the landing obligation and thus fully documented fishing, then fishermen have every reason to be as selective as possible. That is why we should give them responsibility instead of retail regulation. I hope that this will be reflected even more clearly in the future management plans as well as in the rules on technical measures and for discards. I congratulate the rapporteur on his fine and speedy work.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the Common Fisheries Policy is a bad policy. It is impractical and unsustainable and that is as true in the Baltic as anywhere else. This new law shows us the future as the EU sees it: a regional management plan for a virtually closed body of water. So we must ask whether it will work.  It remains collectivised; it is treated as a common resource; it retains the concept of a maximum sustainable yield, taking little or no account of subsidy or illegality or the simple fact that if you try to operate at the limit of its sustainability you have no margin of error. What is needed is restoration of national property rights, so countries can move to a maximum economic yield – a topic where the Australians are pioneering some new sensible thinking. With fishing, as with immigration, the Australians are showing us the way and there is probably much that we can learn from them. But, as so often, the EU is likely to be deaf to reason.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Walesa, on his work and dialogue. The Member States of the European Union undertook in 2002 in Johannesburg to maintain and restore fish sources to levels that can produce a maximum sustainable yield on as urgent an urgent basis as possible, and no later than in 2015. Tomorrow the first multi-year plan will be on the vote and it is our obligation to make this precedent accurate and appropriate.  Many of the stocks of fish need to rebuild their biomass. Thus, the fishing rate has to be established at a maximum sustainable catch mortality level, ensuring that current economic income does not impair its stability for the future.  To ensure that maximum sustainable yield is resilient, a precautionary approach should be used to keep catches at levels 10 to 20% below the maximum calculated rate for fishing mortality.  Setting a target of 80% of fishing mortality to maintain maximum sustainable yield will ensure more future than was promised in 2002.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the multiannual plans under the new common fisheries policy (CFP) must meet the ambition of restoring stocks of fish by setting maximum sustainable yield (MSY) levels plus a safety margin. MSY can at best be an estimate based on scientific advice. If we get it wrong on one side it has disastrous consequences. If we get it wrong on the other side it still gives us the possibility to come back beneficially. That is why we must always ensure in these plans that we have maximum sustainable yield calculated at a level that is sustainable, even if we get it wrong. An extra safety margin keeping stocks above MSY level is essential, in this and in all aspects of implementing the reform of the common fisheries policy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to highlight the three key elements we have on the table here today. First, it is a great approach to have a multiannual plan and to know exactly what we will do in the coming years because it is a great message to the fishing industry and all those who are engaged in fishing. Secondly, I think it is extremely important that the fact that quotas for several species of fish are studied and introduced in parallel is finally approached because this is the only correct way. The previous model where it was practically talked about the fishing of one species of fish is not enough. So, and that's something that's very good in this case. The third important principle is the regionalization of fish catching in European seas. Namely, I used to mention the Adriatic Sea as a small, closed sea, like the Baltic Sea, and we need to have a special sensibility for small and especially closed seas.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I too find this multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea an exceptional... extremely important, especially if it also follows scientific discovers, evidence and, of course, advice. I think it can be a good example of how sustainable fishing should be ensured, how the environment should also be protected and how to prevent excessive fishing. And I think that is exactly what needs to be added: fish are not only threatened by excessive fishing, of course, fish are mainly at risk of pollution. Pollution from humans. And this example of this multiannual plan may also be an example of good practice for other seas, and to mention only the Adriatic Sea, as has been said, certain measures will also be needed there. Above all, the ban or restriction of any extraction of oil in the Adriatic Sea as a closed sea, because this is a serious permanent threat to fisheries, and if we make a wrong move here, then there will be no more hunting or planning.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for this constructive debate which has shown that there is a relatively large convergence of views. I would like briefly to reply to some more specific points which were raised by some of the honourable Members.  First of all, I totally agree with the statement that we are politicians and we should listen, we should rely more on scientific advice for guidance and this is exactly what we are doing in this plan.  With regard to some of the comments made about the Commission proposal, I would like to highlight that the situation with the Baltic sea stocks is quite good. Five stocks out of seven are at maximum sustainable yield (MSY). The Commission, together with the Member States, used to establish fishing opportunities delivering high biomass levels. Now that all the stocks are in good shape and low fishing effort may then cause reduced growth, to avoid this it should be possible to fish temporarily above the MSY. But this is something that ICES has confirmed and we are still adhering to the precautionary approach. I think this point was also mentioned by Richard Corbett.  I also agree with the point raised that different areas, different regions, obviously have different particularities and we cannot adopt exactly the same approach in the Mediterranean as we are adopting in the Baltic. As was mentioned, this is a great step forward and using the same words as were already said, a blueprint for the other multiannual plans.  One Member said that hopefully this will become a reality. It is important now that this plan is implemented so that it becomes a reality, but to become a reality, implementation is of the utmost importance. I do have faith however in the stakeholders in this region.  Mr Mato again spoke about the importance of taking the long-term approach rather than simply the annual approach, and I think that this is very important. This is one of the strengths of the multiannual plans. Again, the Baltic is a very sensitive ecosystem that we need to protect, and this is always kept at the forefront as one of the priorities. With regard to the long-term approach, ICES stated that the ranges are considered applicable for at least the next five years.  To Ms Hazekamp I would say that yes, unfortunately biodiversity is being threatened: not only that of cod but of most species unless we continue, or unless we make it a point that we need, to fish sustainably. Again this is in the proposal and that will help us to rectify this situation.  Mr Affronte, who I know made a very good contribution to all this, said too that this is a test for other multiannual plans. Yes, it is, and that is why we have to get this one right because if we want to look forward to other multiannual plans then we have to get it right first and foremost. I agree with what Mr Santos said as well: that this Parliament is committed to the common fisheries policy reaching its objectives.  Other points were raised and obviously we have taken note of these points, but to conclude I can only hope that after the Council’s general approach last week and after your vote this week, we will soon be able to engage in trilogue negotiations so that we can hopefully reach a political agreement during the period of the present Presidency, the period of the Latvian Presidency. This would then allow us formally to adopt the plan this year which would be an important political signal for the upcoming future regional management plans. I would like to thank each and every one of you for your support in coming up with this plan.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for their contribution throughout the process of our work and in today’s debate, even those with whom I strongly disagree.  I would like to remind you of a very important point. I believe we have to stay true to our word, the word we gave last year when we voted in the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP). In it we understood and we agreed that we should reach certain levels, levels of FMSY (fishing mortality consistent with Maximum Sustainable Yield), levels above MSY, and those levels should be reached by the year 2020. Starting from this year, we should do our best to work in a correct manner in a steady process of ensuring that those levels are reached.  I believe that by tabling certain amendments we are trying to achieve something right now – this year – which is going against the word we have given to the fishermen. Please remember that the common fisheries policy and this multiannual plan and all other multiannual plans are there to create a more stable framework for the future of the fishermen. When we pass certain legislation in this House they have to believe that we want to do everything in our power to ensure that there is plenty of fish in the sea and there remains plenty of work for them to do.  And as such I would like to ask you to support my amendment tomorrow on the ranges from 0 to FMSY, with the note that we will do everything in our power to reach levels below FMSY as soon as possible.  Please remember also that this dossier contains a revision clause which is supposed to be applied in three years’ time, so even if we reach the levels by then we still have two more years to reach the levels that are in agreement with the basic regulations.  Please support me tomorrow and once again thank you very much for your help.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 28 April.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Alain Cadec's report on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulations (EC) No 850/98, (EC) No 2187/2005, (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No. 1098/2007, (EC) No 254/2002, (EC) No 2347/2002 and (EC) No 1224/2009 council and repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 1434/98 on landing obligation (COM(2013)0889 - C7-0465/2013 - 2013/0436 (COD)) (A8-0060/2014).

name: Alain Cadec
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have negotiated for two months the measures that fishermen and national authorities will have to implement in order to implement this reform, which, it must be said, upsets the rules of the common fisheries policy. As I have always said, and I repeat today, the landing requirement will be extremely difficult to implement, particularly for multi-specific fisheries and small-scale fishing. Please, Commissioner, when your services are required to make legislative proposals, you must measure the social, environmental and economic impacts. The measure of requiring fishermen to disembark all catches made during a fishing trip is a generous idea, in itself, because it is intended to encourage professionals to be more selective, and that is what we want.  However, as I said, we see in practice that this implementation will be difficult. Our common concern is obviously to preserve the resource while maintaining a viable economic activity, but I remain convinced that we must focus our efforts on the selectivity of the machines. Fortunately, the agreement we reached in the trilogue helps to mitigate the negative effects.  First, the Commission will have to publish annual implementation reports that will assess the problems faced by fishermen and find solutions to them. These reports will be prepared using data from Member States. Sanctions for non-compliance with the landing requirement will not come into force until 1 January 2017, giving fishermen time to adjust. Measures to prevent the creation of sub-size parallel capture markets will need to be put in place by producer organizations. In addition, measures to facilitate the stockpiling and opportunities of landed juveniles will have to be put in place by Member States. Storage conditions for unsired catches on board have been relaxed in relation to the Commission's proposal - it was necessary - and finally, video surveillance for the inspection will not be mandatory.  You discussed the multi-year management plan in the Baltic Sea in the previous debate. This plan is very important, as everyone has said. It is the first developed under the new Common Fisheries Policy. It will serve as a model for all other plans, as Mr Affonte said, as you said, Commissioner Vella.  With regard to this management plan, I am also very concerned about the attitude of some Member States which, in the Council, are trying to override Parliament's prerogatives. Despite the court's recent ruling in the Venezuela case, which proved Parliament right, these Member States continue to challenge the codecision procedure for multi-year plans. A joint statement by France and Spain underlines, and I quote: "the inadequacy of the ordinary legislative procedure". These Member States also believe that the task force's conclusions on the multi-year plans have not been endorsed by the Council - well let's see! and have no inter-institutional status. However, these conclusions do have a status, that of mutual trust between Parliament and the Council. However, France and Spain want to break that trust.  As Chairman of the Committee on Fisheries, I strongly condemn this attempt to breach the treaties. I therefore call on the Council - it is not there, it is a pity - in all its wisdom, to take a reasonable position. I will not hesitate to go through with the defence of Parliament's prerogatives, if the Council chooses the inter-institutional conflict.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the landing obligation is a vital element of the reformed CFP. It aims to end the wasteful practice of discarding fish back into the sea. Discarding casts a negative image on the industry, has a harmful impact on sustainable stock exploitation and marine ecosystems and affects the financial viability of fisheries. The omnibus proposal you are discussing today, and voting for on Monday, is an important step and will bring legal clarity and create a level playing field for the industry in implementing the landing obligation. I want to specifically thank Mr Alain Cadec and the shadow-rapporteurs for their very hard work and their commitment to find compromises. I am delighted that we have, in the end, reached an agreement that is acceptable to all parties. The compromise text agreed fully respects the basic elements and underlying principles of our initial proposal: to ensure legal clarity, to remove inconsistencies with the landing obligation from existing legal instruments, and to enable proper implementation of the landing obligation. But the next phase regarding demersal fisheries in the north-western waters, the south-western waters and the North Sea is approaching fast, so we absolutely need the kind of legal certainty that the omnibus will now provide.  I am happy to report that the development of discard plans for these fisheries is progressing very well. Member States’ cooperation has evolved, learning from the first experiences with the pelagic discard plans for the 2015 landing obligation. Work with the advisory councils has intensified along the way and the Member State groups are now bringing them more on board in the preparation of joint recommendations. Interaction between the Commission and Member States is also smooth and we are well on track to having plans in place before the start of next year.  What about implementation so far? This is a very important element and here I have to say that we are in close contact with industry and national authorities and stand ready to assist with the policy instruments already available in our toolbox. We have also been in discussion with the Pelagic Advisory Council to set up a Committee with a hands-on assignment to closely monitor the introduction of the landing obligation. Even in the absence of the omnibus regulation entering into law, we have not heard of any major problems since the start of the year.  We have received and replied to a few requests for clarification from Member States and the Advisory Councils, but these have all been relatively minor issues. Cooperation seems to be good between the inspectors of the different Member States regionally, and by and large our information suggests that fishermen are complying with the rules. In conclusion let me say that we are very appreciative of the responsible attitude shown by the Member States and the industry so far. We hope that this will continue to be the case in the future.

name: Gabriel Mato
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the reform of the CFP opens up a new stage for the sector in Europe, and we need to learn to adapt to a new situation: the obligation to land all catches is a good example of this. Some will like it more; others will like it less, but this obligation is already a reality that we have to assume. The objective we have set ourselves is to move towards sustainable fishing, but in order to achieve this, we must also know that measures must be articulated to make the changes we are proposing take action. We must therefore be flexible in adapting our fishermen to the new circumstances and, therefore, I believe that the agreement reached in Parliament on the proposal that there be a period of adaptation to the new obligation before sanctions are applied, as well as the need to submit annual studies or analyses on the functioning of this measure, has been a great step. We have reached an agreement, a good agreement on the 'bus', to clarify a little bit the rules to be applied. And I say 'a little' because the process of change , which is 180 degrees - initiated with the common fisheries policy has just begun and there is a long way to go in which we will have to take measures that require everyone's commitment. In the end, the landing obligation is, as the Commission says, a legal framework for transition. Changes will have to be made in the context of the revision of the Technical Measures Regulation, as well as in the context of the desired regional plans, to address the new situation. What is now urgent is that politicians, entrepreneurs, administrations, fishermen, scientists and other partners come forward and discuss how to implement this obligation in practical terms while expecting a clearer approach with more homogeneous legislation that integrates the experience gained from the first months of its implementation. I trust in the goodwill and commitment of all of us involved in this process to make this new regulation good for our marine environment and, above all, for the future of a fisheries activity that remains key to Europe's economy, employment and future.

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The landing obligation was introduced to prevent the discarding of undesirable fish. The unwanted fish may be too small or not of the right kind. Discarding is a waste of resources and has fatal consequences for ecological and biological diversity, because many fish, which were previously considered undesirable bycatch, are largely thrown overboard dead. Several provisions in existing regulations are no longer consistent. That's why we had to change them. These include minimum reference sizes, rules on catch composition, discards, the ban on fishing in certain areas, etc. In the basic regulation, we have introduced a calendar to make it easier for fishermen to change. It is now important to implement it as quickly as possible.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I support the amendments proposed by the rapporteur, as I believe that such an omnibus regulation must have a clear objective, which in this case would be to gradually comply with the landing obligation and not to put additional burdens on the backs of fishermen.  In my view, the proposed two-year adjustment period is a perfectly reasonable time limit that will allow fishermen to make changes to fisheries policy more easily. I am happy that Croatia has been granted an exemption from the landing obligation provided that the discard is less than 5 percent because such a decision is saving for our fishermen. Due to the fact that swimmers do not provide a sufficiently high level of selectivity when fishing, as well as an evident lack of facilities for the disposal of unwanted catches, Croatian fishermen were put in big troubles that have now been significantly alleviated. I expect the same positive impact on fishermen and the sustainable development of their activity from this rapporteur's proposal and for this reason I will support it in the vote.

name: Norica Nicolai
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Madam President, thank you. Undoubtedly, the purpose of the landing obligation is generous - sustainable fishing, management of marine resources, decreased mortality among these resources; all these constitute values awarded for the new fisheries policy. Unfortunately, however, the legislative package is adopted at the end of 2013, comes into force in 2014 and, although it provides for a set-up period, we are already running late with the implementation of these rules.  The text that we will vote on tomorrow is a text of compatibility, which ensures the coherence of the regulation with the provisions of the new fisheries policy. The fact that this landing obligation comes into force step by step gives it a chance to be sustainable and applied correctly because, in our view, the landing obligation, the way in which it will be implemented, depends to a large extent on the success of the fisheries policy.  What we would like to note, however, is that Parliament has behaved constructively, has tried to mitigate a number of effects which, in negotiations with the Council, it has also managed to promote. We hope that this regulation will be a successful one, although we have enough doubts, because in practice, as my colleague, Alain Cadec, also pointed out, there are unfortunately a number of Member States that are not very happy about this new approach. However, it is our obligation and the Commission to promote and support it, as it is essential, as I said, for fisheries policy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, cuireadh an rialachán seo chun tosaigh mar go mbímid ag fáil réidh le héisc i slí nach bhfuil éifeachtach agus léiríonn sé an easpa inbhuanaitheachta timpeallachta agus an phráinn atá ann chun dul i ngleic leis an bhfadhb. Aithnítear go forleathan go gcaithfear cosaint a thabhairt don timpeallacht ach creidimse go bhfuil sé díreach chomh tábhachtach cosaint a thabhairt dár n-iascairí beaga agus tá siad ag streachailt mar gheall ar na céadta rialacha diana atá i bhfeidhm in earnáil na hiascaireachta. Táim ag iarraidh a chinntiú nach mbeidh tionchar diúltach ag an rialachán seo orthu. Is rud thar a bheith teicniúil atá i gceist agus mar gheall air sin chuireas-sa leasuithe isteach a chinnteoidh nach mbeidh an t-ualach riaracháin chomh dian ar na hiascairí agus táim ag moladh gur de réir a chéile ba chóir an landing obligation a chur i bhfeidhm. Tá sé chomh tábhachtach go mbeimid ag cur iascairí i lár an aonaigh sa scéal seo ar fad mar go minic bímid ag glacadh, agus an ceart againn a bheith ag glacadh le comhairle na saineolaithe eolaíochta ach mura bhfuil iascairí, iad sin atá fite fuaite leis an earnáil, ag plé an scéil, táimid ag cailliúint an scéil go huile is go hiomlán.

name: Louise Bours
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the common fisheries policy is a bad policy. It is impractical, unsustainable and unjustifiable. The last Parliament sought so-called reform but, at best, they are making a catastrophe slightly less catastrophic. Rearranging the deckchairs on the Titanic is the maritime metaphor that seems to come to mind.  Yes, stopping discards is vital, but they are one of the worst aspects of a flawed system. Frankly, a landing obligation which is partial and limited simply does not solve the problem. What is needed is to de-collectivise the policy in a manner which stops the vast French and Spanish fleets hoovering the seas at taxpayers’ expense. Now will Mr Cadec’s proposal achieve this? No, it will not. And does the UK’s Lib-Lab-Con seek to do anything about this? No, they do not. On fishing, as in so much else, the British people need to know that they are being betrayed once again by the British political class and Mr Cadec’s tinkering at the edges does nothing to affect this fundamental truth.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI).
text: Madam President, the landing requirement is unenforceable: it will require fishermen to store the waste in their vessels, which is technically difficult for small-scale fishing, and it will impose an extra cost on them, since they will have to shorten their fishing time and consume fuel for additional journeys. In addition, what will be the final destination of the landed fish? Will they be destroyed or recycled? If the latter solution is chosen, for the benefit of which economic actors? Who will actually take care of the landing? The most reasonable solution would be to reduce releases by improving the selectivity of fishing gear, particularly through new types of trawls. However, if this proposed regulation were still adopted, it would at least have to grant small-scale fishing exemptions or a transition period to adapt. This transition period would allow fishermen to renew their equipment, with full support by the FEAMP, since it is a matter of meeting a regulatory obligation.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, the ban on discards is a very important turn in fisheries management in Europe. Fishermen, as has already been said, will have to make a substantial effort to technically adapt to this new provision, an effort that will be greater in the case of the artisanal fleet. The 'bus' regulation which we will vote on tomorrow aims to eliminate the contradictions between the new discard ban and the rules on technical measures and control. Following intensive negotiations, we have reached an agreement which adds a margin of flexibility to the obligation to land all fish caught. It must be noted that the commercial outings for fish that were previously discarded will be very limited and I believe that from this Parliament we have endeavoured to introduce in the Commission's initial proposal a number of essential amendments to facilitate the european fishing fleet's application of the new Community requirement. The fishing sector needs time to adapt. We know this well in a region like Galicia, where I come from, the first fishing region in Europe; hence the importance of flexibility and graduality contained in the Regulation. Landing all catches will possibly involve some changes in boat capacity and network selectivity, and the fleet, especially artisanal ones, may have practical difficulties that we cannot ignore. We will study carefully in the coming times the impact of the new requirement, and action will have to be taken accordingly. Finally, I would like to point out that the ban on discards also highlights some mismatches in European fisheries policy which have been denouncing for some time from Galicia. The principle of relative stability for the allocation of quotas between Member States remains, but that principle was intended for a management regime allowing discards. The change in discards should lead to a re-examination in the years to come, a rethinking of the current distribution of fishing opportunities.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this 'bus' regulation regulating the landing obligation is, as has already been said, but I think it is important to recognise this – one of the fundamental pillars of the new Community fisheries policy. There is no more discussion: discards had to be ended and the CFP ends these discards. The Regulation, which had to enter into force on 1 January this year, introduces this obligation this year for the Baltic and pelagics. It is a normative change that is , I want to make it clear here, it has been repeated by some people who have preceded me – very important and radical, being their practical application difficult in the private countries. I have to tell you something, Commissioner, which is that I am very concerned about the limited real information that the fisheries sector has; the fisheries sector beyond its representatives and lobbies in Brussels: fishermen's guilds and shipowners' associations do not have much knowledge of this and Member States should be explaining this obligation further.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the fishing industry faces a similar challenge to many other sectors throughout Europe at the present and especially in the agri—food business. It is the challenge of doing more for less, and we need to create a more sustainable and prosperous fishing industry that protects our fish stocks. But Europe can only do so much.  As other speakers have said, the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) in December has put an obligation on fishermen to land their catches, ending the practice of discarding. This is what was asked for, this is what was requested and this is what has now been done. Yes, it may have taken a long time but then sometimes to get things right does take time. So I hope the long-term prospects for the industry will be quite good.  I am extremely pleased that Parliament has been able to secure the much-needed flexibility which was, in my opinion, required and I welcome the transition period because it does take time to adapt to the future, and I would like to give this a fair wind and hope it succeeds and brings better times for the fishing industry.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, let us not forget that the discredited common fisheries policy (CFP) has in fact been one of the principal causes of discards through its inflexibility in the past. Everyone wants an end to discarding, especially fishers themselves. They hate being forced to throw dead fish back into the sea by regulation.  I believe that the landing obligation will only succeed if it is implemented in a thoroughly regionalised and fishery-specific process. This compromise is acceptable, but it is not perfect. It will be very difficult to implement, particularly in the mixed-species white fish sector which is crucially important in Scotland and elsewhere. I therefore welcome the allowance to give time to adapt, but there must also be support for additional methods of reducing unwanted catches in the first place. There must be flexibility to allow quota uplift to prevent the industry being paralysed by so-called ‘choke species’. The overall objective surely must be to reduce fish mortality, not just to move the problem onshore.

name: Marco Affronte (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the obligation to disembark is an important step; One of the objectives of the common fisheries policy is the phasing out of all discards.  It is a kind of revolution and that is why the debate on this draft regulation has been lively and also very complex. In the end, however, it turned at least in part into a missed opportunity. Unfortunately, the result obtained is lower than expected, to the point that it has largely distorted the sense itself and made the results likely to be scarce. Fisheries management is based and will increasingly be based on accurate and complete scientific data. That is why the exception that has been included in the regulation, which excludes small-scale fishing, which is 80% of the total when catches are less than 50 kg, makes no sense.  I am aware of the difficulties this legislation will bring to fishermen, particularly traditional fishermen. Despite this, I preferred an approach that may be more gradual over time, but still a precise objective, the total elimination of discards.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it seems very important to stress that this regulation will effectively mark the transition from the previous common fisheries policy to the new common fisheries policy, which is more focused on holistic sustainability. Finally, the old rejections will be taken into account in the management of water sources, which is fundamental from the point of view of scientific management and which I applaud from a political point of view.  However, this new approach will have side implications that should merit attention. In context, in Portugal there are multi-specific fisheries. In these cases, it is enough to have a species with a depleted quota or zero quota in case of closing the entire fishery. This is the specific case of black swordfish fishing, a centuries-old artisanal fishery, which will be blocked by the impossibility of catching the cat-sandpaper shark, for which a zero quota has been set. The consequences will therefore have to be given careful attention by the Executive Body of the Union.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am pleased finally to be in a position to endorse this report, and I thank Mr Cadec for all his hard work; I know it has been difficult.  I do regret the delay in coming forward, because it certainly would have been useful if we had had these regulations in place for the beginning of the ban at the beginning of this year. I do not think we have got off to the best of starts with the Omnibus Regulation on that basis, and I do hope that fishermen do not lose confidence in Parliament and our stance on discards simply because of that.  I am aware that this is only a ‘quick fix’ to remove inconsistencies in existing legislation until the Commission comes forward with a full overhaul of the technical conservation measures, but I am glad that we have now got that quick fix in place. Having worked on the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) in the last Parliament, I can say that the discard ban was one of the few EU achievements that my citizens welcomed, celebrated and do actually come and talk to me about, so I think it is incumbent on us all to make sure that we go forward, do not lose any ambition on that CFP and get it right.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The elimination of discards is a pillar of the reform of the common fisheries policy. It is estimated that this practice amounts to 23% of the total catch volume. The fight against discards is a priority for us and fishermen will have to shore up all the commercially valuable species caught. It is good that this obligation applies both to fish below the minimum conservation reference size and to fish caught after use or in the absence of quotas. This will result in more reliable data on fish stocks, better management and more efficient resource management, and above all end unnecessary waste.  I congratulate the rapporteur. You have my full support.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the landing obligation is a fundamental change in fishing activity. 2015 will be a testing year for its implementation. This policy aims to protect the environment by putting an end to discards of catches at sea. However, in parallel with the objective of protecting the environment and preserving fish stocks, sustainable fishing activity must be supported. Account must be taken of the social and economic impact of the Regulation on small fishermen in the Member States, because it increases the operating costs of small-scale fishing and traditional fishermen. In addition, investment and increased labour costs are needed.  For this reason, there must be a significant period of adjustment and financial aid and tools should be provided for the adaptation of small-scale fishing to the new system, since the new framework also requires investment in storage and on board.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I apologise, I had a vote in the Committee on Budgets. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, 'zero rejection' was a slogan for the reform of the common fisheries policy, which is now confronted with reality. And, unfortunately, this reality is not that of zero rejection but that of the obligation to disembark. We have moved to shore a problem that we have not been able to deal with at sea, and I regret that we have not always taken the time to face the real problems and to provide the right solutions in terms of the selectivity of fishing gear and fishing practices to avoid this mortality of the resource, in a spirit of European support for fishermen rather than in that of eternal sanctions. The choice to turn these wastes into flour was the choice of the majority, not mine. Is. We will not rewrite the history of the common fisheries policy. Today, we have to deal with this obligation, this requirement, and we know how much it will weigh on the daily lives of fishermen and their work. It is about the viability of fishing companies and activity in the coastal territory.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to point out that I have many friends among the fishermen, and one fisherman from Poreč, who is a small fisherman, is my best childhood friend. And they always like to say to themselves that they're skeptical, suspicious, and they don't really trust law-makers. I'm going to be a little fisherman now, too, and I'm going to be a little suspicious because I'm not sure how this is going to end. Namely, I would like to believe that compulsory landing is equally sustainable fisheries. But let me be a little suspicious and not make sure that's the case.  In any case, I want to highlight the need that the principle of flexibility and the principle of the transition period may be to banish my doubts and perhaps flexibility and transition period will allow small fishermen to feel better after a few years when these directives come into force.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, discards of fish overboard without the possibility of survival is an unsustainable practice and a cause of a fair revulsion, a practice with very diverse causes ranging from the absence of commercial value of fish that would be in good condition to be consumed to management measures to poor management. What is important is to understand the huge diversity of situations that characterise fisheries in the European Union and to realise that the implementation of this provision of the common fisheries policy has completely different requirements if we talk about multi-specific and predominantly artisanal fisheries or in the monospecific and predominantly industrial fisheries of the north.  There are still unanswered questions, as we have recently seen in the delegation of the Committee on Fisheries to the Azores. Who pays the maintenance costs on board the fish? Who is responsible for your collection and referral? Who guarantees the costs of these operations? These were issues that, once again, the sector raised. During the discussion here of the reform of the common fisheries policy, we made amendments to respond to them. They were made unfeasible by the majority, but the questions, these, continue to be asked by the sector.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Thus, these are regulations which have as their main objective, in particular, the economic, environmental and social aspects, which, in fact, are not as clear in the present case as the Commission maintains. Sometimes these rules seem to be quite slightly removed from the practice, and the question of how realistic they can also be implemented. There is a risk that these rules may cause more harm than the benefits themselves on those essential elements that make them even more effective. And, Commissioner, you talked about cooperation with industry and inspection, you were talking about surveillance. However, it is also necessary to talk to fishermen, so it is necessary to carry out analyses, to collect information, to plan in a way that also allows sustainable fishing, and that is why, in my opinion, it is necessary to reconsider the content of these regulations.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for this interesting debate. Some Members have again highlighted a number of challenges that will be faced in the implementation of the CFP reform. We all have a common interest, which is to strengthen fishing and make it a sustainable industry. So we have to take on the challenges and work together collectively to strengthen our important fishing sector. As was mentioned, the transition is from discarding to landing bycatch, but the ultimate aim is to reduce and to try and eliminate bycatch as much as possible. One way of doing this is by going for more selective gear, while the landing obligation also promotes this idea. We have also to keep in mind that, when protecting the industry, we are doing this in the best interest – and in the interest of the long-term sustainability – of fishermen themselves. Some Members mentioned the need for flexibility. Flexibility does exist, with the de minimis provisions and quotas, which will be adjusted to take into account the discards as well. As many have mentioned, the omnibus is a temporary reform of technical measures. Other multiannual plans will follow and the review of control regulations will follow as well. We are not leaving fishermen on their own. I would like to remind you that the EMFF provides support for our fishermen as well, for example by helping them to change their gears and in the handling of catches onshore and on vessels. Mr Cadec went back to the previous debate and mentioned the legal issue between Parliament and the Council. I do not know whether I should even come back on this, but allow me one comment. This was indeed one of the points of discussion in the Council, but I am happy that the Council approved the full general approach and did not exclude the point relating to the legal basis. Here, the Commission is fully committed to the conclusions of the interinstitutional taskforce.  As I underlined at the beginning, all the actors involved take their respective responsibilities seriously, and cooperation is working well. So I am certain that any outstanding problem on the ground that has been mentioned can certainly be addressed. Commission Statement  Commission statement referring to Article 1(11) point 2 (amendment of Article 19(2) of Regulation (EC) No 850/98), Article 2(6) point 1a (amendment to Article 15(1a) of Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005) and Article 3(4) point 1b (amendment to Article 15(1b) of Regulation (EC) No 1967/2006) The Commission interprets the provision in Article 1(11) point 2, Article 2(6) point 1a and Article 3(4) point 1b of this Regulation relating to the measures to facilitate the storage and the finding of outlets for undersized catches once they are landed, as applying only where such measures are relevant and necessary.

name: Alain Cadec
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for the quality of this debate. I would also like to thank all those involved in the drafting of this report: the shadow rapporteurs, the secretariat of the Committee on Fisheries, our advisers, the European Commission - Commissioner - and the Latvian Presidency, without whom all this would not have been possible. I would also like to thank my assistants, Emilie and Vincent. The landing obligation will need everyone's support if it is to be properly implemented. It is about the credibility of our institutions and the common fisheries policy. I hope that cooperation between the Commission, the Member States, Parliament, professionals and scientists will enable the relevant implementation of this obligation, to the benefit of the resource and the fishermen, because I still think it will be difficult, as I told you earlier in my opening remarks. Selectivity remains the real answer to this problem.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 28 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: in writing. –  It is four years since the now famous ‘Fish Fight’ campaign against the wasteful practice of discarding fish at sea kicked off in the UK, with the backing of nearly one million Brits. Their tireless campaigning helped ensure this reform was firmly on Parliament’s agenda. Labour MEPs’ firm support for this helped secure the hard-fought-for reform of the CFP to end the practice of discarding – which was hailed as a major success, even by Greenpeace. This week we are voting on measures to bring existing laws in line with the reform, to ensure legal clarity in the implementation of the landing obligation. It is our duty to ensure that this process is done in the clearest and most coherent way, without delay.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. It was very important to reach a compromise with the Council quickly in order to remove regulatory obstacles to the application of the new landing obligation and to ensure full legal certainty for all the fishermen concerned.  I am very pleased that the Council has taken on board Parliament's concerns about the implementation of this provision. In this respect, I believe that it is right and widely acceptable to give fishermen two years to 'adapt' before any sanctions are imposed. Furthermore, the annual report to be presented by the Commission on the basis of information provided by the Member States and advisory councils will enable us to respond in a timely manner to the inevitable difficulties faced by fishermen and national authorities in complying with the new obligation. We will then have the opportunity to correct the regulation if necessary in the event of a critical issue and to assess whether we are on the right track.  Finally, let us not forget that although the objective of the ban on discards should not be called into question, the entire fisheries sector should be guaranteed adequate support so that this waste-generating practice can be phased out without entailing excessive administrative burdens for fishermen and supervisory bodies.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the CRP).

name: József Nagy (PPE).
text: - Dear colleagues, Last week, there was a high-level popular public hearing on the protection of indigenous minorities in the European Parliament. A clear message from the experts who spoke and meps: the EU must move on. We must adopt minimum standards for minorities in the EU and set up an institutional system to enforce them. I propose that we establish a two-pillar system of protection of minorities in the Union, where Member States can continue to define indigenous national minorities recognised by their legal systems. These minorities, on the other hand, need to set a minimum EU standard. At the same time, Member States retain the power to broaden these minimum standards to meet local needs.  Why do we need change? This is not the first time in this House that a warning has been issued that minority policy in Europe is a source of constant tension and cannot be put off any longer. It would be nice to remember that strong empires, monarchies and national alliances collapsed because they didn't pay attention in due course... (the President withdraws the floor)

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the technological development of renewable energy and its lowering are going to be a reality and — yes or yes - they will be decisive in changing Europe's energy model and in combating climate change, but it will also be a reality — yes or yes — that reach the consumer and that the necessary democratisation of energy will come true , despite the locks that some try to impose on us. That is why we ask – and we believe that it is important – a balanced regulation, which is basic, as I say, to try to prevent these locks from a reality that is coming and will come soon. In addition, it is of particular importance for certain territories, such as the island, in particular the Canary Islands or the Balearic Islands, or for the Iberian peninsula, where energy dependence and dependence on an energy that is polluting and expensive make models and regulations like this crucial.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! It is five years since the tragic moment when the president Polish and nearly 100 representatives of the Polish elite in a plane crash near Smolensk, Russia. So far, Russia has not given away either the wreckage of this plane or the black boxes, and recently we had a plane crash in the Alps and a joint Franco-German investigation into the matter and records from black boxes appeared instantly. It's like an example of how you want to be able to do it. And if you want to block something, it locks up, as the Russians do. I would also remind you that in September 2010 the European Commission proposed that this investigation should be internationalised and helped with experts. President Barroso did the same in 2010. I think we should go in that direction.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, colleagues and colleagues, one third of its citizens live in rural, remote and mountainous areas of the European Union. Their GDP is 70% of the average, while in urban areas it is 123%. The trend of leaving these areas has increased the crisis so that from 2008 to 2012 unemployment in these areas rose from 7% to 10%. The easiest way to approach these areas is the internet.  The Internet doesn't just mean fun, it doesn't just mean information, it means education, it means the availability of health care, administrative procedures, starting a business and ultimately staying in those areas. However, only 18% of these areas are covered by the internet, three times fewer than urban areas. And that is why the Digital Union needs to be used for greater coverage of the high-speed internet of rural areas in order to reduce the gap between them and urban areas.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, certainly some of you have seen in recent days the image of Don Rodrigo Rato, who was minister of the Economy of my country with Aznar, managing director of the International Monetary Fund and President of Bankia, arrested by the police for fraud, money laundering and uprising goods. These days we have learned that one of his top historical collaborators, Mr Luis de Guindos, the current Minister of Economy in Spain, has sufficient support to be president of the Eurogroup. Then they will say that the problem in the Eurogroup is Mr Yanis Varoufakis. Ladies and gentlemen, corruption is not only tackled by criminal measures, but also with political will.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So, the new annual report of the European Food Safety Authority highlights the high levels of different types of pesticides in food. And the results of control activities in the Member States of the European Union, Iceland and Norway showed that 685 different types of pesticides were found in just under 81,000 samples of processed and unprocessed foods. 27.3% of the fruit and vegetables analysed contained more than one type of pesticide and the highest proportion of pesticide types was found in strawberries, peaches, apples and lettuce. One in eight cases of strawberries contains residues of even more than six different pesticides. It should be stressed that the current dietary standards are, in the opinion of the Agency, such that they do not sufficiently protect consumers from toxic mixtures that are not safe and therefore this exposure can have many, even negative, effects on the health of consumers, and therefore this must be put to an end.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the earthquake in Nepal, at least 4 000 dead and unfortunately will increase.  There are hundreds, only among European citizens, tourists who still do not give and cannot give news of themselves. Kathmandu has now become a tent city because of the devastation and there are still fears of further collapses and, above all, the first international aid has to deal with an airport that is completely bordering on collapse. Morgues are already completely over the edge of capacity, and experts can only say that the worst is yet to come. More than a million children are at risk and the spectre of epidemics is practically around the corner. 6 500 are injured, I remember.  A minute's silence is not enough, we must immediately coordinate our efforts between all the Member States and ensure a prompt return for our citizens but, even more so, concrete aid for reconstruction. I have said it before: a minute's silence is not enough, I would like a minute's commitment from this Parliament.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI).
text: Mr President, the Eulex mission was established in 2008 to help Kosovo become a rule of law. It is the largest civilian mission of the European Union. It is clear today that it has failed! Suspicions of corruption even hang over three of its senior officials. French lawyer Jean-Paul Jacquet was tasked with investigating. In the report he has just submitted, he confirms that serious malfunctions have occurred. A figure he gives on page 16 sums up Eulex's failure: in 2012, Kosovo was ranked 105th country in the world in terms of resistance to corruption; in 2014, it was only 110th. As a result, it has dropped 5 places in two years. The Jacquet report proposes solutions to improve Eulex's effectiveness, but I am pessimistic about its chances of being heard, because the European Union is radically unfit to restore order in a country so plagued by organised crime.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have already said many times that terrorism is a problem that has to be tackled internationally. Let me here put the question whether the EU is cooperating enough with other countries. More specifically, I am talking about countries not far from us: Israel, Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. Of these countries, only the cooperation with Turkey can be defined as good. I therefore urge the Commission to develop more cooperation with Israel, Jordan and Egypt in the fight against terrorism and human trafficking.

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, a large meeting was held in Bucharest on 1 May 2010. At that time, thousands of people witnessed the launch of a new party, the National Union for the Progress of Romania, on the political scene. This week, we are celebrating five years since its inception and I am speaking to you from the membership of the party that has managed to impose itself on the political scene through seriousness, determination, promoting fairness and, above all, by being a party that keeps our word. Today, UNPR is the second largest political party in Romania, with more than 350,000 members. As a parliamentary force, UNPR is the third party in Romania, with more than 50 MPs in the two Houses. We are the main ally of the Social Democratic Party, with which we form the Centre Left Alliance, and the President of the UNPR, Mr Gabriel Oprea, is the Deputy Prime Minister of Romania.  THE UNPR has always promoted stability internally and is a supporter of the rule of law, of the right balance between the fundamental powers of state, which must guarantee independence, justice and the fight against corruption. UNPR is a party that promotes respect for human dignity, opposing discrimination in society. The fact that I, ethnicRoma, was supported by the UNPR for the position of European parliamentarian is proof of this.  The National Union for the Progress of Romania will systematically promote the centre-left programmes in which it believes and which Europe and Romania need. In view of the main public policy project of (...) (the speaker is interrupted by the President)

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the President of the Spanish Government denied, last week, direct access by the police forces in the Basque Country and Catalonia to the schengen system databases. Both police officers are assigned the security of ten million Europeans: Mossos d'Esquadra and Ertzaintza are the eyes and ears of European intelligence in these territories and want to contribute and receive data. Spain prioritizes an old and old concept of state and national security over coordination, which we have defined in Europe as the first key to effectively addressing the threat of international terrorism. Spain further forgets that this option has hindered the fight against other terrorism – fortunately disappeared – and has been used to limit operability and discredit the work of police forces marginalized by this decision. For safety and efficiency, I call for real coordination among all European police and announce initiatives here in order to achieve this.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the infamous troika, we were told, has left Portugal, but what is true is that the policy of extortion, theft and confiscation of Portuguese workers has continued. Not formally by the troika, but now under close scrutiny of the European Commission in the framework of the European Semester and in the name of compliance with the Budgetary Treaty. If anyone here thinks that one can be against the troika and in favour of the European Semester, they are wrong, because they are exactly one and the same. Proof of this is the stability programme presented by the Portuguese which continues the cuts in wages, cuts 600 million euros in pensioners' pensions in order to destroy public social security, points to another 400 million in cuts in public administration, which will mean more redundancies and less public services, while lowering the taxes of large capital. More and more workers say that they will not be entitled to a decent life without a break with the rules of the Budgetary Treaty and the euro designed to benefit them at all time.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like, from Aragon, to draw your attention to what can be considered one of the most important environmental problems in southern Europe. For twenty years, lindane residues, an insecticide substance that is now banned in the European Union, were deposited in the town of Sabiñánigo, next to the Gállego River. It is estimated that in total there can be about 400 000 tonnes, poured without any control. Lindane is a bioaccumulative product that affects the entire food chain. The consequences on the environment, health and the economy are terrible. It is necessary a plan of environmental decontamination of the area, as well as rehabilitation of the basin of the Gállego River, a river from which for many years the population has been drinking. But the Governments of Aragon and Spain have only signed a protocol that does not establish binding obligations. Very little is done, with scarce resources, and lindane upticks continue to occur above legally accepted limits. The European Union cannot remain oblivious to an environmental crisis which will have terrible dimensions if we do not act soon.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, the confrontations between the Greek government SYRIZA - ANEL and the Troika in the Eurogroup, despite the noise that is being made, do not concern the popular interests but only which share of capital will benefit from the forthcoming unpopular agreement which will mark a new long-term attack on wages, pensions, new privatisations, etc. The two sides are united in their anti-grassroots aggression and differ only in the manner and time of its manifestation. The government, at the behest of the Troika, is grabbing the available public bodies, municipalities, insurance funds, to pay a debt that the people do not owe, thus exacerbating the problems in municipalities, regions, hospitals, schools, universities. Unpopular memorandum laws remain intact while the government gives millions in fines to companies for tax fraud and smuggling, always with the help of the European Union, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund.  The unpopular policy in Greece continues and the European Union escalates the attack on the peoples. The responsibility now lies with the workers: only with a popular alliance can they overturn this policy, no matter what government implements it.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – With the support of the European People's Party, we held a public hearing last week on the situation of national minorities in Europe. The presentations of the experts have highlighted the need for further action by the Member States, in particular the Member States that joined after 2004, because there is a huge gap between the possibilities of legislation and practice. With regard to Romania, this was acknowledged by Head of State Johannis in a message sent to the 12th Congress of the RMDSZ. A few days later, however, the paragraph on this was removed from the official Presidential Communique, because some people realised that this was diametrically opposed to the position that the Romanian State was also trying to take before international for a, that the minority issue had been settled in an exemplary manner and that no further action was needed. This is not the case at all, the Romanian Head of State knows this, but there seem to be some things that even the President should not talk about in Romania: that the Hungarian community in Romania still has many unresolved problems.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: Mr President, rampant deflation, unemployment at its highest, sluggish growth, this is the state of Europe after seven years of crisis, marked by austerity policies that are as ineffective as they are dramatic for the peoples of Europe. It is time to break with the blind application of ever more rigid rules and take a step closer to federalism, to finally give the European Union real economic governance. Yes, the 2008 crisis has shaken our economies, but it is the disunity of our states that explains our mirth.  While we should come up with a comprehensive strategy for the European Union, some are still blind to the reasons for this crisis: the pusillanimity of heads of state who use European decisions for their short-term electoral concerns and who forget the essentials, the future of the peoples of Europe. Economic and fiscal policy decisions must no longer be in the hands of the representatives of the States, but must also be entrusted to the representatives of the European people, in this Parliament. This is a necessity, because it is by moving towards more federalism that the European Union can really act for its citizens.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to draw the European Commission's attention to the very difficult situation of milk farmers in Poland. As a result of the Russian embargo, milk purchase prices have already fallen by around 20% compared to the pre-embargo period, while at the same time farmers will be subject to penalties for exceeding production limits for the second year in a row. These penalties will amount to as much as €200 million and will be collected from payments to farmers for ongoing milk deliveries in the coming months, while prices for the raw material delivered to the collection points will fall. Despite the Commission's decision to spread the payment of these penalties over three years, this will be a serious burden for Polish milk producers of around 60-70 cents per litre, which is almost 70% of the current milk price in purchase. In this situation, after the payment of penalties, the remainder of the income derived from the sale of milk is certainly not sufficient to cover the costs of production, and that means losses and inability to pay the remaining obligations of dairy farms, including credit obligations.  I therefore ask the Commission once again to take an interest in the situation of dairy farms in Poland and to prepare solutions to support this production throughout the European Union.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, recent developments in the Mediterranean have made us pay more attention to EU immigration and refugee policies. However, I would like to raise concerns regarding attitudes that have been shared in public by some Baltic politicians. They argue that the Baltic States already have too many ʽown immigrantsʼ and cannot invite more, even from the territory of other Member States. The term ʽown immigrantsʼ refers to Soviet era settlers and their descendants, mostly Russian speakers. This approach is inappropriate. The Baltic States regained independence almost a quarter of a century ago. We can hardly compare Baltic Russian speakers who were born or have been living there for many decades with refugees or potential immigrants who are only considering emigrating to Europe. These excuses deprive Russian speakers of their right to European solidarity and also undermine the cohesion of the Baltic societies. I regret that once again we are seeing malicious attempts to use the negative historical experience of the Baltic States to get some sort of preferential treatment at EU level.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – In Hungary, there was a general public outcry that the European Commission commissioned a company to carry out development policy analyses, whose name coincided with political corruption and the free robbery of privatisation. A company with a mandate of four people and a mandate of HUF 1.5 billion is the preparation of this analysis. He is 100% owned by the failed Socialist prime minister and is still a leading politician today. I ask the Commission how this can happen in the case of a Commission which is very aerated in principle, so that no ambiguity can occur with the mandates. I call on the Commission to terminate the contract with Altus Zrt immediately, as this goes against the Commission's code of ethics to the maximum. By the way, I can imagine the transparent procedure by which such a company can be selected.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we have just commemorated one very unhappy anniversary two years after the Rana Plaza disaster. Poignantly, Rana Plaza occurred two days before another sobering commemoration, that for the International Workers’ Memorial Day, which has been held on 28 April for many years. Today some people seem to think that European workplaces are perfectly safe. For example, the Commission rightly has a focus on ‘better’ regulation but many, including the British Government, have wrongly interpreted this as meaning ‘laxer’ regulation. That is inexcusable, given the appalling toll of work-related mortality and morbidity.  In my region, the South-East of England, ten people were killed at work last year, over 9 000 suffered an injury and an estimated 184 000 were made ill by the work they did. That is enough to fill two Wembley Stadiums. We could have no better demonstration of the need for health and safety legislation than these sobering statistics. National and European legislators should heed them more.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, next Thursday Jean-Claude Trichet will answer questions from members of the Irish Parliament banking inquiry in Dublin. One question has haunted the Irish psyche over the past number of years and that is: just what role did Mr Trichet and the ECB play in the decision to pay, in full, unsecured and unguaranteed bondholders in insolvent Irish banks. Were the Irish authorities threatened with punitive financial measures if they did not pay the bondholders in 2010, and later on in 2011?  Ashoka Mody and Ajai Chopra, two senior IMF officials who were part of the Troika, have both since stated that they supported haircuts for bust banks, but were overruled by senior management in the IMF and the ECB. Yes, it was a time of crisis and contagion, but in my opinion the ECB exceeded its remit. It violated the Treaties by insisting that the Irish authorities bail out insolvent banks and impose the full costs on Irish taxpayers. Mr Trichet must answer these questions in a full and frank manner because this goes to the heart of European democracy.

name: Renate Sommer (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The city of Kyrenia exemplifies the occupied northern part of the Republic of Cyprus. It is a legitimate wish of those displaced from there to be able to return to Kyrenia and their other home towns. Time is pressing, because in the north of Cyprus facts are being created on a daily basis, which will make reunification more difficult. Nature and landscape are permanently destroyed by the occupiers. Entire mountains are dug up to extract building materials. Huge hotels are tarnisling the beaches. Large mosques of Turkish design displace the remnants of Cypriot building culture. Will it finally become a Turkish province? I believe that the cultural and religious heritage of Cyprus must be preserved. It must be allowed to restore churches and also to celebrate divine services there.
