That is why the bi-communal technical committee must continue to be funded from the EU budget, as must the missing persons mission. This is a humanitarian act that can help reunite both parts of the island in peace.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D).
text: – The emergency summit following the latest tragedy in the Mediterranean did not make bold decisions. Some Member States have refused quotas for refugee resettlement, refused to participate in rescue operations. Do we give a clear account of what is happening at the external border of the European Union, which receives thousands of refugees monthly and where resources are depleted? The only measure adopted is the increase in triton money.  Europe cannot act as a fire brigade after every new tragedy. We need a long-term policy adopted by Brussels and the 28 Member States.  If today's attention is focused on the Mediterranean, tomorrow the events can put to the test the land border between Bulgaria and Turkey, where it is already complicated enough. More than 5,000 illegal immigrants entered in the first three months of this year alone, 60% more sought protection. It is not enough just to save people, as the situation in reception and refugee centers borders on a humanitarian catastrophe. Dublin 3 needs to change and teams involving FRONTEX must be formed for rescue operations and border protection.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: Mr President, with the crisis, many companies are facing collective redundancies. It is essential to put in place accompanying measures to ensure the reintegration and retraining of the staff concerned. Indeed, many states have provided for such schemes. This is particularly the case in Belgium, where the conversion cells have proven their effectiveness. Nevertheless, I would like to draw attention to the particular situation of cross-border workers. They do not always have the opportunity to benefit from such support, precisely because of the lack of cross-border arrangements. The European Commission should be able to tackle this problem by proposing a form of European cooperation between the various support services. This could be done in particular with the help of the European EURES network. It is important that all European workers, cross-border or not, can benefit from such schemes.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I stand to give my condolences to the friends and families of those affected by the tragic earthquake in Nepal. Countless people have lost their loved ones and I share their grief.  Knowing the country and the people well – as a former Chair of this House’s South Asia Delegation I was indeed heavily involved in the dialogue on transition to democracy in Nepal – I do think that it is apt that we are showing our solidarity with the one-minute silence.  I also welcome the EUR 3 million in emergency aid released by the Commission for this tragedy, in addition to assistance offered by the EU Member States and the deployment of experts. It is essential that these Member States work and coordinate effectively, with the Commission and also with the other donors, to ensure that we have learnt the lessons from the past; for example, in the aftermath of the Haiti earthquake in 2010. These resources must be used in the most effective way. Chief amongst them was the failure to coordinate and I do think it is important ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the National Union for the Progress of Romania is a centre-left national political movement that aims to implement, in Romania, a government based on progressive programmes, reform, and to ensure the political, economic and social stability of the country. UNPR is primarily aimed at young people in need of early-career support and guidance, young families in need of support for raising and educating children, active generations, all those who believe in a better life in their country.  The UNPR believes that investment in human resources, especially in young people, is the key to development, the key to a society's progress. The population and, in particular, the young population are the central element in defining and structuring any strategy for sustainable socio-economic development. Now, more than ever, Romania needs a realistic and coherent strategy on its economic and social development for the coming decades, and the younger generations must be the major factor in such a strategy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes this item.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of the report by Krystyna Ybacka on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process (2015/2039(INI)) (A8-0121/2015).

name: Krystyna Łybacka
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report, which I am pleased to present to you, is a joint contribution by the Committee on Culture and Education to the continuation of the implementation of the Bologna Process. It is also a clear and strong call from the European Parliament for higher education ministers to take concrete action and commitments on the effective reform and implementation of the Bologna Process. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs, CULT Members, NGOs and the European Commission for working together on this report effectively.  The Bologna Process is an attempt to organise a higher education system in Europe so that it becomes widely understood, accessible, trustworthy, while remaining diverse or even boasting of its diversity. Our report focuses on assessing this process, on the issues that need to be improved and on the new challenges that this process has to face – such as youth unemployment, the economic crisis or demographic change. Although the Bologna Process has achieved a great deal over the last 15 years in terms of quality of education, mobility and recognition of academic diplomas, there are still many areas where urgent action is needed.  We consider it necessary to carry out the jointly agreed reforms in the countries of the European Higher Education Area consistently and to strengthen the bottom-up approach. There is also a need to focus the teaching process more on the student. What matters is the results of education – what the graduate knows and knows, not necessarily how he learned it. We also need clear and clear communication on the Bologna Process in order to raise citizens' awareness and support for higher education reforms. There is no doubt that the recognition of qualifications acquired abroad, periods of study abroad and previous education should be improved. This would directly benefit students. It should be possible for any student studying in any country of the European Higher Education Area to recognise their qualifications throughout the European Union. To achieve this, we need better strategies and practices to further improve the recognition of qualifications, to implement a European credit transfer and accumulation system and to develop and implement national qualifications frameworks.  An important priority for many countries is to improve the quality of higher education and to establish quality assurance systems. Increasing social inclusion and equal opportunities for access to education and the international mobility of under-represented and vulnerable groups remain a challenge for the Bologna Process. It is also important to strengthen the link between higher education and research by facilitating dialogue between the scientific world and society and promoting the beneficial applications of technological innovation in teaching and learning. Continuous investment, more effective use of available funds and the development of new funding models are essential. The objectives of the process cannot be achieved without sufficient funding for higher education. The Bologna Process is not only a 3+2+3 system, but a series of quotas that must lead to the creation of a European higher education system. That's what we expect from...... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are very tight in time. I have well over ten speeches for the five minutes we are actually entitled to. They therefore allow me to make decisions on this. I cannot take into account colleagues who have been able to speak earlier today. I ask for your understanding. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Firstly, I would like to thank Mrs Krystyna Łybacka for a high-quality and comprehensive report on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process. The Bologna reforms have resulted in the creation of a European Higher Education Area and significant acquis has been made over the last 15 years in terms of making higher education systems more comparable, mobility, the provision of quality assurance systems and the recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. It is essential for cultural, economic and social development that the higher education sector is coherent, transparent and of good quality.  For European higher education, the Bologna objectives are the essential tool to cope with the current challenges. However, there are still problems, some Member States do not recognise the diplomas of all institutions, and I believe that this should certainly be improved in order to achieve this in space.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – I would like to thank Mrs Lybatzka personally for her report. Over the past 15 years, the Bologna process has made significant progress in terms of mobility and quality of education, but today it faces new challenges such as youth unemployment. I believe that active dialogue between the university community and business should be stimulated in order to develop curricula that arm the young with the necessary skills for a smoother transition to the labour market.  Another important step in this direction is the need to recognise qualifications acquired abroad, as well as periods of study abroad, including skills acquired through non-formal and informal training.  Last but not least, access to international mobility should not create conditions for discrimination against students with more modest financial opportunities. Investment in quality education is the key to tackling youth unemployment.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR).
text: – Mr President, praise for cooperation is often heard in this Chamber and even more so in committee, but the extent to which this was achieved over the Committee on Culture’s work on the Bologna Process was of a different, if you will excuse the pun, degree. Much of the credit for that goes to the rapporteur and the ECR will support this report in plenary. The report is not so consensual as to simply reel out platitudes. It is not just ʽmotherhood and apple pieʼ, to use the American expression, but it is of some real value.  However there are storm clouds, in the shape of the possible admission of Belarus into the Bologna Process, as is currently under discussion. There are already countries in the process whose political systems give less than full-throated support to the democratic freedoms and plurality needed for an effective university sector, and the admission of Belarus would give even more cause for concern over the confidence we want to have in the process.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, creating a European higher education area was the target for 2010. We are in 2015 and we fill our mouths indicating that the knowledge economy is the most timely outlet for the crisis we endured for so many years, but this debate takes place at untimely hours. The list of professional accreditations is very short; it is still very difficult to approve titles between countries; and, in Spain, for example, Bologna has served as a pretext to seriously damage equal opportunities: university fees are much more expensive and scholarships have been eliminated for the second cycle. Talent, only talent can generate prosperity for our countries and, in the case of countries like Spain, this, with Bologna, has gone backwards.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the implementation of the Bologna Process does not escape the trend of cuts and privatisations of public services, in this case higher education. In our case, in Euskal Herria, the right to develop a truly own educational model and the right to study fully in our language, Basque, in all cycles of higher education, remains pending. The Bologna plan drives an education system obsessed with competitiveness, with young people trapped in full time and drowned out by fees that many and many can no longer afford. Education should integrate—not exclude—and should help create critical students. We want a public education that thinks about people, not the needs or interests of private companies, which is becoming more and more evident; a participatory education, where students have a voice, art and part of it.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to conclude that this is a comprehensive and ambitious report – congratulations, Mrs Oybacka – which knows how to recognise the path traveled, the progress made, but it also points out the reforms, the outstanding issues and all that needs to be done yet, which is a lot. In that regard, I would just like to add , to which a main objective has already been rightly said, that of achieving real convergence between the different degrees of implementation of the European countries, which have applied it to a very different extent. Bologna, if this is achieved, can be a great instrument of real European construction from below, precisely from its network of universities. And one more question. There are two objectives in the report: 3% of GDP devoted to R&D in 2020, and 40% of the population between the age of 30 and 34 with a university degree. If this is achieved, the success will be enormous. And finally, this report will see its contrast at the Yerevan Conference in Armenia in a fortnight. There we will see the reason for this Parliament.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by One of the objectives of the Bologna Process was to support the mobility of students and lecturers. It must be acknowledged that significant progress has been made in the internationalisation of higher education. What is worrying, however, is the reluctance of students to use the Bologna Process or the Erasmus programme. This reluctance is due to two factors: concerns about language qualifications and insufficient funding. It is therefore necessary to consider measures that could solve these problems. Perhaps expanding the use of erasmus intensive language courses would encourage students to go abroad. It is also worth considering increasing scholarships even while reducing their amount or making them dependent on family income.  In addition to these problems, the structural flaws of the Bologna process hampering mobility should also be pointed out. The rapporteur mentioned one of them, i.e. difficulties in transferring ECTS credits. Students going to a foreign university very often have trouble with the recognition by the parent unit of the subjects passed there and have to re-pass the exams. The second drawback is due to the 3+2 education system. In practice, the only opportunity to go to a foreign university is the first degree, during the two-year master's degree it is difficult.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – And I, for my part, would like to join my colleagues who congratulated Mrs Lybatzka on the balanced report. We cannot help but appreciate the progress made so far in the field of higher education through the reforms undertaken under the Bologna process, namely improving the quality of education, improving mobility, internationalisation of knowledge and a number of other achievements of the Bologna Process. Dear colleagues, in the 21st century knowledge is a resource that is was exhausted faster than any technique. I therefore believe that European higher education must aim to provide the highest possible level of knowledge through continuous updating of curricula. It is essential for the sustainable integration of young people into the labour market that curricula enable the combination of knowledge with professional skills, promote the development of entrepreneurial skills, exploit the potential of new technologies and digitisation in order to develop a wide range of skills. It is necessary to promote dialogue between higher education institutions... (speech interrupted)

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – I congratulate the report prepared by Prof. Rybacka and would like to express my support for the main demands contained therein and for the substance of the document itself – for the continuation of the changes taking place in higher education through the implementation of the Bologna Process.  The Bologna Process aims to create a European Higher Education Area where students can choose from a clear range of high-quality courses and benefit from efficient recognition procedures. Bologna reforms help European universities improve their competitiveness and attractiveness towards the rest of the world. Thanks to compatibility between education systems, students and job seekers can move more easily in Europe. Mobility of higher education is also important, which concerns not only the structure but also the proper organisation in quality assurance. Mobility is a key element of the European Union's education and training programme, as well as Erasmus+, which supports projects promoting cross-border cooperation with higher education institutions.  The European Higher Education Area has ushered in major changes in education systems, so it is still important... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to discuss this report and to say that the Commission welcomes the report ʽFollow-up on the implementation of the Bologna Processʼ and would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the result.  This report gives a good overview of developments since the Bologna Declaration, which was signed in 1999. It recognises the complex and broader context that higher education and the Bologna Process operate in. The Bologna Process has transformed higher education systems in Europe, and many member countries have made significant changes in order to bring a common higher education area into being.  As the report acknowledges, countries have modified their higher education structures and established mechanisms for better mobility, recognition and quality assurance in education. They have addressed ways of improving the social inclusiveness of higher education and ways to equip graduates with employable skills, to deepen how higher education contributes to society.  These reforms support core issues at the heart of EU policymaking too, by promoting social inclusion, enhancing learning mobility and employability of European citizens, as well as promoting the international competitiveness of higher education in Europe. But many of the commitments are still only partly implemented. The Commission continues to argue for wider and deeper implementation, and for this it is crucial to fully involve the academic community and relevant stakeholders, as Parliament’s report also underlines.  On the road towards a fully-functioning European higher education area, we face particular challenges and opportunities that we expect will be addressed at the Ministerial Conference in Yerevan on 14 and 15 May this year. The issue of youth unemployment and how higher education systems can ensure graduates have employable skills is at the top of the agenda and, in the light of the recent attacks on fundamental freedoms and knowledge inside and outside of Europe, we expect that Ministers will also address the contribution of higher education to maintaining democratic and inclusive societies in Europe.  Ensuring that higher education is properly inclusive of all sectors of society is indeed a constant challenge. Recognition in the wider sense is important for reaching talent where talent lies, for promoting more flexible learning paths, and for ensuring lifelong learning. Other challenges that the communiqué is likely to address go to the heart of the teaching and learning process and it is essential that we continue to put students at the centre of this process, in using the ECTS credit system or in quality assurance mechanisms, for example.  Last but not least we expect technology-enabled learning to be one of the main points on the agenda at Yerevan. New modes of delivery and a better use of online tools are crucial and offer a variety of opportunities for creating even more high-quality international education institutions, students and staff. The aim is the same as with traditional mobility – to ensure high-quality learning and teaching.  The Commission acknowledges Parliament’s call to help reinvigorate and indeed accelerate the Bologna goals. It also agrees with Parliament’s contention that education is one of the main pillars of society when it comes to promoting jobs and growth, and that necessary funding must be guaranteed when tackling youth unemployment.  Reforming higher education boosts the quality and reputation of Europe’s learning institutions, mobility and internationalisation, while at the same time generating sustainable growth and jobs. Therefore, it is absolutely vital that countries continue on the path of structural reforms, modernising and internationalising higher education in Europe to improve quality, transparency and trust.  The Commission welcomes Parliament’s call for countries to implement the agreed reforms and to support those countries encountering difficulties in this. We both recognise the challenges that have their roots in the different context and circumstances of the various member countries. The Commission agrees with Parliament that countries should be supported in delivering on their commitments, for instance through partnerships or working groups to ensure better peer learning.  The Commission has been a strong advocate for including targeted peer learning measures in the Bologna Process work plan, to support full implementation, and I am pleased to note that through Erasmus+, the EU is already supporting countries’ Bologna reforms. Last year, 20 programme countries received funding to address identified gaps in implementation, and the capacity-building strand of Erasmus+ provides support to the remaining members of the Bologna Process.  All our efforts for reform in education must be underpinned by the sharing of democratic values, in order to ensure an open, inclusive space for higher education to help sustain the future of Europe and its next generations. In this spirit, Commissioner Navracsics looks forward to participating in the coming Ministerial Conference and adopting a communiqué fit for the future.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 28 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The introduction of the Bologna Process into national higher education systems was unquestionably the right step for Europe. Only by investing and improving the academic and educational process for students in the European Union will we achieve economic growth, a reduction in youth unemployment in the future, and we will also have a chance to face the demographic changes to which the European Union will be exposed in the future as a result of an ageing population. The Bologna Process has achieved a great deal over the last 15 years, but it needs to be revived in order to respond together to the new challenges facing Europe. We must work hard to bring higher education systems closer together in the Member States of the European Union through common rules of cooperation.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Bologna is a beautiful Italian city, for decades symbol of the left and university knowledge. But in a strange reversal of values, it is also the city chosen to start the process of commodizing training and the knowledge we are discussing here today. When students, researchers, faculty and public university workers went out on the street in defense of their rights, they knew well what awaited them: the precariousness of employment and their progressive devaluation to serve large companies, so that, as in medieval universities, only intellectual conformism is rewarded with an increasingly irrational system. But above all, they anticipated the breakdown of the central axis of education policy: the compensation of starting inequalities. As seen in the 3+2 commitment, the university is expected to act as an economic filter by which social inequalities are camouflaged and perpetuated.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. – A recent survey by the German Chamber of Commerce and Industry has shown that German companies are dissatisfied with the bachelor's degree and, in particular, criticise the level of skills learned. Students are also often dissatisfied with their courses. They complain of too much bureaucracy, schooling courses and the loss of academic freedom. The objectives of the Bologna reform, international mobility and greater practical relevance, have not been met. Diverse, individual study opportunities at any level were standardized or harmonized and grown structures were damaged. Evaluation and equalization pressure consume resources. Both students and business have recognized this deficiency and are pushing for the master's or degrees that are similar to our traditional model. At the same time, industry bemoans the lack of graduates of dual vocational training, because forced academisation will lead to many young people being smuggled into higher education institutions that would have been better off in the high-quality dual education system. Instead of correcting mistakes, the experiment is being pushed to increase the international mobility of graduates. The aim is to make it easier for unemployed young people from the euro crisis areas to move around the world, thereby reducing youth unemployment. As a result, we see that this request can only alleviate the symptoms of the euro crisis, but does not address its causes. In the long term, the crisis countries of southern Europe will no longer be able to develop prospects without their young people.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – If students and teachers are asked what has changed most with the Bologna Process in Higher Education, most will tell you: the costs of higher education have increased immensely for students and their families, while reducing the quality of curricula by reducing the period of each cycle. In short, today, a student who does not have the financial capacity to pay the very high tuition of a second cycle, and assuming that he will have money to bear the costs of the first cycle, will always have a level of qualifications that puts him at a disadvantage in the search for a job, which throws him almost inevitably into precariousness. The Bologna process has elitist higher education, exacerbated inequalities between students, put large companies in the direction of institutions, to the detriment of the representation of students and other members of the university community. None of this is necessary for cooperation between institutions and student mobility. What is needed is for governments to invest in free and quality public education for all, supporting, above all, students with fewer resources. What is needed is for the EU to stop putting pressure on its budgets, making that objective impossible.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is bogdan Brunon Wenta's report on European film in the digital age (COM(2014)0272 - 2014/2148(INI)) (A8-0123/2015).

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: Rapporteur. – Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. In my speech today, the film, the European film, will play a central role.  In 2014 , a year of great success for the European film industry, almost 1,500 European films were produced, twice as many as American films. By contrast, the number of viewers who watched European films turned out to be inversely proportional. Most European films are shown only in the country where they were shot, and they rarely travel to other countries. Europe is a leader in the production of films in the world, but they are not always watched by viewers. We need to change that. And it is thanks to the film that we have the best opportunity to promote cultural diversity, learn the history and traditions of our neighbors. That is why, in my report, improving the distribution and promotion of European films is a key point.  In addition to cinema, which of course is the most important place for film screening, we have more and more opportunities for legal access to films on the Internet or via video on demand. In this context, there is room for innovation and a little more flexibility in media chronology. The European film industry should seek new business methods and distribution channels, increase the cross-border provision of audiovisual services and the portability of European films, thereby ensuring that EU viewers have access to an ever-growing and richer film offering through a growing number of platforms. However, the European film industry needs a stimulating environment in order to make full use of its cultural and economic potential, which will encourage investment or diversity of creation. One of the solutions to better circulation of films is to increase the number of European films with subtitles, as well as dubbing. Nowadays, when digital copies have replaced analog film tapes, translating subtitles is much cheaper and it is possible to add them in different languages to one copy of the film. Numerous film festivals, such as Cannes, Berlin and Karlove Vary, and lux prize films, which help european films reach a wide audience across Europe, play a major role in the promotion of films. A great example is the film "Ida" by Paweł Pawlikowski, which initially had a low viewership in Poland, and the huge notoriety and success in our country managed Polish to achieve only after receiving numerous European awards and an American Oscar. Of course, all these objectives will not be achieved without adequate funding. That is why creative Europe and the MEDIA sub-programme are so important, as well as funding at regional or Member State level and funding opportunities from the European Investment Fund. Public funding should focus more on expanding the audience of European films and increasing aid for international promotion and distribution. A very important point of the report is also the call for film education and, more broadly, media education at all levels of teaching from an early age. Film education enables citizens, especially young viewers, to use the media critically and bring them into the world of film art.  I would also like to stress the need to archive the film heritage for future generations. It is important that Member States adopt legislative measures that improve the level of digitisation by collecting and transmitting mandatory film copies. In conclusion, my report is only the beginning of a debate on the potential of European film in the digital age, which I hope will continue at the European Film Forum and will also be reflected in the legislative proposals announced by the European Commission, which parliament and the audiovisual sector as a whole are waiting for.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We actually have to keep to 11 p.m. I said earlier that I would take a few more speakers because there were only two members on the list of speakers. In catch-the-eye, we now have only colleagues who have spoken before. I would therefore ask for your understanding if I remain with these two who had already registered at that time. In this catch-the-eye procedure, I will only give the floor to Mr Caputo and Mrs Adinolfi. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the strengthening of copyright and privacy protection is a strategic element through which a full development of creative capacity and self-expression takes place. The latter find maximum expression in the film work in which the combination of numerous intellectual skills is realized, more than in other artistic manifestations.  To this definition must be added the essential economic connota. The sector contributes to economic growth, creates jobs and promotes innovation in the European digital market. Consequently, this artistic ecosystem needs copyright and that the latter is genuinely guaranteed, the rightholders, in particular the authors, adequate compensation. In any case, what makes me think most is the development, with the help of technologies, of a real digital neorealism that needs an increase in protection sometimes from the point of view of privacy, sometimes copyright and sometimes both. I would like to see joint harmonisation, such as dual protection of copyright and privacy, and it would be appropriate to set up a committee to deal with the definition of the concept of a work of art in 2015.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my studies have enabled me to get to know perfectly well the problems of those who want to embark on a career in the audiovisual arts, such as, for example, the difficulty of access to credit for cultural enterprises to which, in my opinion, the European Commission has provided hitherto ineffective answers.  European cinema and productions must be protected, especially when the nation states, instead of protecting our production system, grant derogations from the obligation to invest 10% of the revenue in the production of European works. In Italy, for example, the Communications Authority has granted a derogation of millions of euros to the American multinational Walt Disney which, by mortifying us, has made it impossible to find productions of sufficient quality to be transmitted in its channels, to the complete detriment of our creators and our workers.  Cinema has a social, before a commercial, function, and our task must be to protect and spread European culture, breaking down geo-blocking and committing ourselves to the creation of a full digital single market.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the support on the current state of play of the European film sector and the useful recommendations it includes. I wish to thank the honourable Member Mr Wenta for delivering this document. It is in line with the Commission’s diagnosis on the European film sector and the policy orientations that are presented in its communication of May 2014 on European film in the digital era.  Parliament and the Commission recognise the value and wealth of European films. We also agree that the main weakness of the European film sector, compared with its US counterpart, is reaching out to wider audiences, especially across borders. In 2013, 1 546 feature films were produced in the European Union and only a very small fraction of those films were released in countries outside their countries of production. Of course this is linked to a number of factors, for example the linguistic and cultural diversity of the EU, the fact that European films are mostly financed with support from national or regional public funds, as well as the very small size of production companies active in the European market.  At the same time we believe that the sector needs to be encouraged to develop new business practices and to reap the benefits that digital technology can bring for this purpose. So the Commission has launched a stakeholder dialogue called the European Film Forum, which has as its main objective to bridge the gap between European films and their audiences.  There will be structured dialogues with Member States’ public bodies, the film industry and other stakeholders in conferences or in smaller groups in different locations on issues such as: the overall efficiency and effectiveness of policies in support of films, regardless of whether they are national, regional or European; the need to develop new working methods and business models in the face of today’s digital revolution; new strategies to increase public awareness and interest for European films and stimulate dialogue within the audiovisual sector on the impact of the forthcoming copyright reform; and review of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive in the context of the digital single market strategy.  Operationally the European Film Forum will adopt different formats depending on the issues discussed. Conferences, round table discussions, workshops and expert group meetings will be held and the first deliverables of the European Film Forum will be shared at a major public event due to take place in Brussels in the last quarter of next year. Parliament will of course be involved in this process. Furthermore, allow me to draw your attention to the European support programme, Creative Europe, and its media strand. This programme will continue to play a key role in promoting and distributing European films across borders. It promotes distribution in theatres, in particular through the network of Europa Cinemas. Furthermore TV programming as well as video on demand services receive support.  More recently the programme has taken over the preparatory action on the simultaneous release of films in cinema theatres and through video on demand, which provides incentives to the sector to innovate in the way that films are released. The Creative Europe guarantee facility makes available seed money to mobilise private investment and thus encourages the sector to become less reliant on public funding.  As for the Cultural and Creative Sectors Guarantee Facility, the Commission and the European Investment Fund will launch this new financial instrument for the benefit of audiovisual and other creative SMEs early next year.  In conclusion, at this time marked by the digital revolution, it is essential that a creative industry such as the film sector remains at the forefront of innovation. The Commission and the Creative Europe media programme will support this course in the coming years.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 28 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – Madam President/Lord, first of all, I would like to thank Member Bogdan Bruno Wenta for his high-quality and comprehensive report on European film in the digital age. I appreciate your work. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. I consider it important to strengthen efforts to improve media literacy, and in particular film literacy, within the school curriculum and in cultural educational institutions, and for Member States to develop initiatives covering all levels of formal, informal and non-formal education and training at national, regional and local level. I would like to highlight the support for educational films for young people and the support for competitions to encourage young people to create audiovisual works. Thank you for your attention.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. – European film faces new challenges in the digital age, particularly in economic terms, as digital distribution channels and business models open up great potential for the European film industry. The cross-border availability of European films within and outside the EU is of particular importance. In this context, the rapporteur is also opposed to geo-blocking, which may lead to a restriction on the international distribution of audiovisual services. It also criticises the illegal downloading of film content and calls for a binding legal framework and a level playing field for film marketing and online availability. New funding methods such as crowdsourcing are also addressed in the report. In general, the digitisation of film art and a compulsory levy for digital formats are called for.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the context of mr Wenta's very good and comprehensive report, I wanted to emphasise the importance of media education. The increasing mediaisation of modern culture makes media education a very important part of general social education. This is particularly true for young people whose development and perception of the world is partly shaped by the media. I fully agree with Mr Wenta that integrating media literately into school education programmes at all levels in the Member States is important for shaping critical thinking skills and the development of communication and media competences. In addition, watching European films is one way of learning about the language, culture and traditions of other countries.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The digital age has made a lot of changes. Some industries have developed even more, others have had difficulty identifying how to use the opportunities offered by new information technologies. The film industry is a sector that today is at the moment when it has to make a decision integrating the advantages, but also the changes caused by the digital age.  I welcome a report focused on the new challenges launched to the film industry, and I call on the EC and fellow MEPs to reflect together on the best mechanisms by which we can do so. As a person from the digital industry, I believe that we need to stimulate the adaptation of the European film industry to this new era by providing additional funding, creating dialogue groups, supporting initiatives that help preserve our cultural traditions and the memory of European film, or supporting private initiatives that respond to competition from other countries in terms of film distribution.  To do this, one aspect is paramount: digital education! We need to facilitate and support the mechanisms by which future filmmakers, but also those working in the industry, are prepared for the challenges of the digital age.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The aim of the report is to support the promotion, distribution and visibility of the European film. There is no doubt that the European film industry should develop within a legal framework that will encourage investment, diversity and enable the development of new online services. It is necessary to ensure the effective distribution of European films, which will make them noticed and reach a wider audience. It should be borne in mind that national or regional support schemes are focused on the production phase and that European Union programmes offer an opportunity to support underfunded and equally important areas such as distribution and promotion. It should be remembered that film is a cultural good, constant contact with European films is one of the best ways to learn about the history, culture, traditions or language of European neighbours. At the same time, it is also an economic good, as the audiovisual sector contributes to economic growth, creates jobs and fosters innovation in the European digital market. Supporting the report on European film in the digital age will allow all Europeans to benefit from their cultural heritage.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Elisabeth Köstinger's report on "A new EU forest strategy: for forests and the forest-based sector" (COM(2013)0659 - 2014/2223(INI)) (A8-0126/2015).

name: Elisabeth Köstinger
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work Our forests and forestry provide very good answers for an additional economic pillar and at the same time are the best guarantors of quality of life, sustainability, jobs and added value. With more than 3.5 million jobs, the forestry sector ranks third in Europe in terms of employment, directly behind the metal and food industries. More than 452 000 forest-based farms contribute 7% to EU economic growth. Only 60% of the annual offspring are taken in across Europe. Wood is therefore an important and, above all, European resource with great economic importance for rural areas and beyond. The careful care and sustainable management of European forestry companies and more than 16 million forest owners ensure that forests fulfil their ecological, economic and social functions. More than 50% of Europe's forests are privately owned. Guided by these figures, I have drawn up my report. The aim is to further strengthen forests and the forest-based sector in their social, economic and, above all, ecological role, to put the raw material of wood first as an important resource for Europe and, above all, to make sustainable use of it. The key points of the report include, for example, better coordination at European level. Energy, environmental, climate and economic policies have a major impact on the management of forests. Forests need to be better positioned in the various European strategies, while respecting the rights of the Member States. Furthermore, a very important demand on my part is not to create new bureaucratic hurdles for forest owners and foresters. Parliament is therefore strongly in favour of a clear separation of forest management plans and management plans for Natura 2000. This Parliament does not support the mere passing on of these public duties to forest owners. It is also important that there are no legal obligations on cascade use, but a real resource efficiency for the sustainable use of wood, and this is also required. Criteria for sustainable forest management are also important, which must also be a quality seal and are constantly targeted and targeted at the entire sector. Here it is important that there is no one size fits all criteria, but above all a strong focus is placed on regionality, taking into account, of course, the Forest Europe criteria, sustainable criteria as the basis for sustainable certification systems. Of particular importance for sustainable forest management as an economic factor and a workplace guarantor are also the so-called green jobs, which forestry supplies with its raw material wood and which make a particularly important contribution to environmentally-oriented production and also to education and training in this area, above all through sustainable forest management. Another important point is research and development. This has also been highlighted in particular. Our goal is to support new production possibilities and product ideas here, especially further development in the field of bioeconomy, environmental protection and climate change. And once again, a particularly strong focus on a low-bureaucratic implementation of the forest strategy. This is really about setting real priorities for growth, employment and investment. I also believe that we should upgrade the Standing Forestry Committee and strengthen its mandate in order to be able to involve the Member States more closely here. I would like to express my sincere thanks to my colleagues in the Committee on Agriculture. We have worked very well together on this, but above all the opinion of the Committee on the Environment and the Committee on Industry has contributed a great deal to the success of this forestry strategy and the position of the European Parliament. However, i would like to thank the assistants, who have worked very extensively, and, above all, the secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture. Thank you very much for your cooperation!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We also have far too many speeches in the catch-the-eye procedure that follows. I will only be able to allow those Members who have not spoken before to speak. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the floor. I would also like to say a few words about the new forestry strategy. It is right and it is important that forest policy should, in principle, be regulated at national level. However, it is equally important and necessary that European action is taken, especially in the face of cross-border challenges in the forest and forestry sectors. Many things are on the right track – and I would like to support the previous speaker, Mrs Köstinger, on many things – the triad of economics, ecology and social issues, but also the very great importance of forests for rural areas and for urban areas and, of course, the commitment to the sustainable management of the entire area. These things are on the right track. But some things are open. Here, too, there are three things to mention: it is very important that we get European sustainability criteria. It is essential that we think about the fact that, although forests are constantly growing, there are also limits to their use in the forest. And it is important that we speak out in favour of intelligent usage concepts in the future. This includes cascade use. Not compulsory, of course, but it is also part of it. For us to succeed, we need good cooperation. That is what I am advocating in the near future.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – The report on the new European Union Forest Strategy can only be positively assessed. I fully share the report's general thesis that we need a systematic, planned and new approach to forest sector management. I would also like to stress that I fully support the fact that forest policy should be a national priority and there is no need to properly introduce Community regulation. I agree that on some issues that indirectly concern the forest sector, we also need common measures at European Union level – investment in the forest sector, more jobs, support for the sector, which can also give greater added value. But here is the place to say that not everything in this sector is at a good level. I'il give you a few examples. With European money, a forest is illegally cut in the implementation of a European project in banya village, Razlog municipality, Blagoevgrad region. That's unacceptable. Separately, in Europe there is also the so-called a 'wooden mafia' engaged in illegal timber extraction exported to Member States or to third countries. We can no longer turn a blind eye to this and other similar degeneity phenomena. As regards funding issues, much more investment is needed, both under European funds and public funds from Member States for forests.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank Mrs Köstinger most warmly for this own-initiative report with the 28 compromises. We have put out a strong political message for forest owners and forestry. It is particularly important to me that the ownership and ownership rights of the 16 million private forest owners are strengthened and preserved. There must be no mandatory forest management plans and no cascade use, and we strongly reject interference with Natura 2000 and Habitats regulations. We very much welcome the research. Forestry is the best guarantee for quality of life, sustainability, job security and value creation, especially in rural areas. Forest conversion and climate change work on voluntary measures. I now call on the Commission to include this own-initiative report in the forestry strategy.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I hope that, at such a late evening, we will be discussing such an important issue as the forestry strategy does not illustrate the triviality of the matter. Yesterday I was walking near Brussels in a blue forest of flowers. I come from a country, Finland, where there are only more protected forests than belgium's surface area.  It is a pleasure that forest resources in Europe are increasing rather than decreasing. We are talking about renewable resources at a time when Europe is interested in natural resources and what we are doing after fossil fuels and what we are doing in the challenges of climate change. Forests, renewable energies and the bioeconomy are the solution.  Although the Member States have the greatest responsibility for implementing the issues, the Commission also has an implementation programme planned. I would like to see a more improved approach in which the Commission sees opportunities for the bioeconomy through research and development, and also everything that is already being done: three million jobs, sustainable construction opportunities and know-how for the processing of the wood sector. I hope that the Commission will also be transparent towards Parliament, because there is a lot of interest here.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Köstinger very much for her report. I believe that much sustainable forest management is currently being constrained by well—meaning but overly prescriptive and bureaucratic environmental legislation, and that includes things like the EU Timber Regulation. So I welcome the report’s emphasis on the upcoming review of that regulation and a call for a new regulation that reduces unnecessary costs and reporting requirements for Europe’s foresters.  I do understand the need to apply the regulation to third country imports, but a blanket approach in the EU is not necessary. Targeted activity is what is needed, and to work with those problem countries to look at how to strengthen their internal governance procedures so that the vast majority of woodland owners across the EU are not burdened with unnecessary cost and pointless bureaucracy.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would just like to take this opportunity to say something about the importance of forestry and the importance of trees, the importance of wood. There are three main reasons for this importance: first, tackling climate change; second, creating jobs; and third, improving health.  On the first of these, tackling climate change, we already sequestrate – absorb – 10% of our carbon emissions at the EU level through our forest cover. If we could increase that forest cover, and I believe we can – in the Republic of Ireland they are going to go from 10% cover to 18% cover by 2050 – we will sequestrate more carbon and play a better role in tackling climate change.  Secondly, we can create a large number of new jobs in this area – in my own constituency of the North-East there is big job potential. And, thirdly, we can improve people’s health by getting them out exercising in forests. So tackling climate change, creating jobs and improving health all show why man’s best friend is not the dog: man’s best friend is the tree.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, even though it is at a late hour, it is a pleasure to be with you tonight to discuss this important issue. I am pleased to represent the Commission in areas where other colleagues are associated with the implementation of our new EU Forest Strategy – in particular Commissioner Vella, Commissioner Bieńkowska and Commissioner Arias Cañete, to mention but a few. In this sense, all of us would like to thank Parliament for its interest and engagement with the EU Forest Strategy, and in particular the rapporteur Elisabeth Köstinger and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this very important own-initiative report. We are glad that the EU Forest Strategy was also discussed in the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Let me start by saying that, while we do not have a common forest policy, the EU has a long history of contributing through its policies to implementing sustainable forest management and to Member States’ decisions on forests in line with the principle of subsidiarity. We have common values, objectives and common concerns regarding European forests and their future. Moreover forests, covering 40% of the EU land area, are an essential element in our environment, our economy and our society.  Several EU policies have an impact on forests, including rural development, climate change, industry, environment, bio-energy and the broader bio-economy. Through these policies the EU also makes a very important contribution to the implementation of sustainable forest management and Member States’ decisions related to forestry and the entire forest-based sector, as well as forest protection. From a political perspective too, I would like to underline that the new forest strategy is very much in line with the political guidelines of the Juncker Commission. For example, the strategy addresses the issue of growth and jobs, not only in forestry but across the forest-based sector. We should not forget that the EU forest-based industries represent about 7 % of EU manufacturing GDP and almost 3.5 million jobs, in particular in rural areas. Obviously this varies from Member State to Member State, given the large diversity of forests in the EU. For a country like Finland, let me just recall that when we include pulp and paper, roughly one quarter of its total exports come from the forest sector – but the services and the economic and social environment benefits that they provide to citizens are common to all Member States. Therefore the forest strategy aims to ensure that such an important natural resource for our economy and society will continue to deliver its economic benefits in spite of new challenges such as climate change and related threats.  But this is not all. The strategy also relates to climate change as it contributes largely to both climate mitigation and climate adaptation. It relates to biodiversity, as forests host a significant part of EU biodiversity and half of Natura 2000 zones are forests and other wooded land. It relates to energy: forest biomass continues to be the most important source of renewable energy and currently accounts for around half of the EU’s total renewable energy consumption. It also relates to other broader areas such as the race for innovation and skills, or the contribution towards sustainable bio-economy. As I said, forests are very different in the EU from Finland to Malta, from Portugal to Romania, so it is clear that the principles of subsidiarity, proportionality and better regulation will be at the core of the implementation of the forest strategy.  When you look at the strategy itself, the basic aim is to establish a framework for forest-based actions and support for sustainable forest management, based on the coordination of the different forest policies in Member States and of EU policies and initiatives relative to forestry and related forest-based sector activities. The strategy provides a holistic approach to forest management, it covers the economic, social and environmental benefits of forests. It takes an integrated approach covering internal and external forest policy issues and addresses the whole forest value chain, considering the important contribution that the sector can make to growth and jobs in the EU and, as I said, particularly in rural areas. Therefore, in accordance with the Council conclusions on the forest strategy, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States and stakeholders, is developing a multiannual implementation plan of the EU forest strategy, which will contain the specific actions to be carried out by the Commission and the Member States, with clearly defined outputs and a timetable for implementation. Stakeholders will also be fully involved in this implementation. This will also increase the synergy between the work done by different Commission services for the implementation of the strategy, and it would facilitate stocktaking. So the timing of the initiative is very good and the Commission will carefully consider this Parliament report in the preparation of the multiannual implementation plan of the EU Forest Strategy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 28 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – We all know that the economic and social and environmental importance of forests in the international, European, regional and national context is generally well known and legitimised, in part, in the relevant cooperation and financing programmes. That is why I consider it necessary to apply a sufficiently developed and eligible legal framework at European and national level so as to strike a balance on support schemes.  I believe that the European Union must act to support, coordinate and supplement the actions of the Member States with regard to forestry policy around the objective of ensuring the sustainable development of the forestry sector and to increase the quality of life of European citizens by strengthening all the goods and services that forests provide in the economic, social, cultural and environmental fields.  I also appreciate that a possible reform of the European Union's policies on forests must not only be reduced to the challenges brought about by climate change, but must also take into account all aspects of the contribution of forests to sustainable development at regional, European and international level.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – Firstly, I would like to thank the reporter for making excellent proposals to define the main directions of the EU forest strategy. These directions are in the same way as the Hungarian ideas and interests. I am particular pleasure that the report states in the first place that any attempt to bring forestry to Community level is unacceptable to the European Parliament. Hungarian foresters are also asked to respect the local and regional character of the sector and the competences of the Member States. I fully agree with the fact that the EU should support national policies in order to achieve active, multifunctional, sustainable forest management, including management of different types of forest and strengthening cooperation against cross-border challenges such as forest fires, climate change and natural disasters. Forests and forest managers play a prominent role in the life of the countryside, without them the development of the countryside is inconceivable. Forestry should therefore be adequately supported within rural development programmes under the 2014-2020 CAP. The Hungarian rural development programme adequately supports our forest. Finally, it is also thanks to my contribution that the report deals with the prioritising of wood as a sustainable raw material in a separate chapter. I support the resource-efficient use of wood and there should be no legally binding prioritising of wood use.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Polish forestry is a model for the concept of sustainable development – a model that the European Union refers to in almost every document. The fact that this is the case is evidenced by the UNESCO Award awarded to Polish State Forests in 2013. The new EU forestry strategy for forests and the forest and wood sector must not overlook the interests of state forests. I therefore do not support Mrs Köstinger's report. Furthermore, the strategy assumptions set out in the report do not take into account the relevant objectives. I would like to remind you that carbon dioxide is the gas of life, and the management of this gas is the basis of ecological engineering for the regeneration of agricultural and forestry soils, the development of the desired biodiversity and the production of a renewable energy source such as biomass. Unfortunately, in the compromises, it did not take into account the important amendments for the state forests, which I tabled with my colleagues from the Polish delegation in the ECR Group. I will therefore vote against this resolution.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. – About 40% of the European Union's land area is covered by forest. The evolution of the context of climate change enhances new risks, such as the higher occurrence of fires and pests and diseases, which require the greatest attention of public policies. Only in this way will it be possible to preserve the multifunctional role of forests and promote their sustainable management. This debate and reflection on this forestry strategy is welcome to promote an approach towards these objectives. This approach should underscore the notion that the value of forests is beyond their commercial-only value, directly linked to woody products. The value of the forest also counts its various functions, such as the protection of soil and water resources, carbon sequestration and the protection of landscape and biodiversity, as well as the value of activities related to hunting, grazing and recreation. And it is this value that must preserve and enhance.
